ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Chief of police. 
(a)  Office established. The office of chief of police is hereby created in and for the city. 
(b)  Appointment. The chief of police shall be appointed to his office by the city manager and shall be accountable to and serve under and at the will of the city manager. 
(c)  Duties. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to enforce all laws and city ordinances and discharge all of the duties prescribed for the city marshal by state law. He shall also perform such other duties as may be imposed upon him by the city council. 
(Ord. of 12-28-1943, §§ 1, 2; Code 1962, §§ 18-1-18-3; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 6-4-1998; Ord. No. 2000-07, § 1, 3-16-2000) 
Cross reference- Officers, § 2-31 et seq. 
Sec. 62-2. - Authority to arrest with or without warrant. 
    Any police officer of this city shall have the authority to arrest, with or without warrant, any person violating any state law or any provision of this Code or other city ordinance within such officer's presence or within his view. Any such officer may also arrest, with or without warrant, any person found in a suspicious place or under circumstances which reasonably show that such person is guilty of some felony or breach of the peace, or threatens or is about to commit some offense against the state law or against this Code or other ordinances of the city. Also, when it is shown by satisfactory proof to a police officer, upon presentation of a creditable person, that a felony has been committed and that the offender is about to escape, so that there is no time in which to procure a warrant, such officer may, with or without warrant, pursue and arrest the accused. 
(Code 1962, § 18-4; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 2, 6-4-1998) 
Sec. 62-3. - Civil service classifications within the police department. 
    The civil service classifications and number of authorized positions within each classification for the police department are as follows: 
Position Number of 
Authorized Positions Assistant Police Chief 1 Captain 1 Sergeant 6 Police Officer 12  
(Ord. No. 2010-22, § 1, 10-21-2010; Ord. No. 2011-19, § 1, 10-6-2011; Ord. No. 2013-21, § 1, 11-7-2013; Ord. No. 2018-15, § 1, 9-20-2018 ) 
Sec. 62-4. - Body worn cameras. 
    The city chief of police shall adopt a body worn camera policy as required by, and in compliance with, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code ch. 1701, subch. N, as amended. 
( Ord. No. 2017-01, § 1, 1-19-2017 ) 
Sec. 62-5. - Release of information recorded by body worn cameras. 
    The release of information recorded by body worn cameras is subject to the provisions of V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 1701.661 as amended. 
( Ord. No. 2017-01, § 1, 1-19-2017 ) 
Sec. 62-6. - Fees for obtaining copies of body worn camera recordings. 
    The city police department shall charge fees for obtaining copies of body worn camera records as set by the Attorney General of the state pursuant to V.T.C.A., Occupations Code ch. 1701, subch. N, as amended. 
( Ord. No. 2017-01, § 1, 1-19-2017 ) 
Secs. 62-7-62-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INTERLOCAL ASSISTANCE 

Sec. 62-31. - Authorized. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 362, the chief of police of the city is authorized to assign regularly employed law enforcement personnel of his department to assist any other county or municipality in this state, when a state of civil emergency in such other county or municipality has been declared by proper authority, upon request by such proper authority, and when, in the opinion of such proper authority, a need exists in such other county or municipality for the services of additional law enforcement officers to protect the health, life and property of such other county or municipality, its inhabitants, and the visitors thereto, by reason of riot, unlawful assembly characterized by the use of force and violence, or threat thereof by three or more persons acting together or without lawful authority, or during a time of natural disaster or manmade calamity. 
(Code 1962, § 18-5(a); Ord. No. 1970-3, § 1, 4-9-1970; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 3, 6-4-1998) 
Sec. 62-32. - Status of officers assigned to city. 
    Whenever any law enforcement officer of any other county or municipality is assigned to the city under authority of an order adopted by the governing body of such other county or municipality, to assist under circumstances as described in section 62-31 which may exist in the city, such officer shall be a peace officer of the City of Port Neches and shall be under the command of the chief of police of the City of Port Neches while so assigned, and he shall have all the powers of a regular law enforcement officer of the City of Port Neches as fully as though he were within the county or municipality where regularly employed, and his qualification, respectively, for office where regularly employed shall constitute his qualification for office in the City of Port Neches and no other oath, bond, or compensation shall be made. 
(Code 1962, § 18-5(b); Ord. No. 1970-3, § 1, 4-9-1970) 
Sec. 62-33. - Compensation and benefits of city officers serving outside city. 
    When any law enforcement officer of the City of Port Neches is ordered by proper authority to perform peace officer duties outside the territorial limits of the city, he shall be entitled to the same wage, salary, pension, and all other compensation and all other rights for such service, including injury or death benefits, the same as though the service had been rendered within the limits of the city, and he shall also be paid for any reasonable expenses of travel, food, or lodging, as well as for damage to equipment and clothing, and medical expenses, which he may incur while on duty outside such limits, or while traveling to or from such assignment. 
(Code 1962, § 18-5(c); Ord. No. 1970-3, § 1, 4-9-1970) 
Sec. 62-34. - Reimbursement to other jurisdictions for expenses of officers assigned to city. 
    When any law enforcement officer is assigned to the City of Port Neches from another county or city under the circumstances described in section 62-31, and upon request of the proper authority of the City of Port Neches, the City of Port Neches will, upon proper request, reimburse the county or city furnishing the services of such law enforcement officer for his actual expenses of travel, food, and lodging, and for such cost of damage to equipment and clothing resulting from the services of such law enforcement officer in the City of Port Neches and for which the county or city where he is regularly employed has paid. 
(Code 1962, § 18-5(d); Ord. No. 1970-3, § 1, 4-9-1970) 
Secs. 62-35-62-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POLICE RESERVE FORCE 

Sec. 62-51. - Name. 
    There is established in the city a police reserve force, in addition to the regularly constituted police force of the city, and the name of such organization shall be the "Port Neches Reserve Police Department, Port Neches, Texas." Members of the police reserve force shall be appointed at the discretion of the chief of police and shall serve as peace officers during the actual discharge of their official duties. 
(Code 1962, § 18-41; Ord. No. 1971-16, Art. I, 9-7-1971) 
Sec. 62-52. - Qualifications. 
    All applicants appointed to the police reserve force shall meet the minimum physical, mental, educational and moral standards established by the commission on law enforcement officer's standards and education, but the police reserve force standards may be stricter than the standards of the commission. The minimum training standards established by the commission for reserve police officers shall be identical for those standards established for peace officers in permanent positions and must be fulfilled before a person appointed may carry a weapon or otherwise act as a police officer. All applicants for appointment must be at least 21 years of age, be in good physical condition and reside within 35 road miles of the Port Neches Police Station. 
(Code 1962, § 18-42; Ord. No. 1971-16, Art. II, 9-7-1971; Ord. No. 2010-12, § I, 6-17-2010) 
Sec. 62-53. - Duties. 
    Members of the reserve police department shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police and may be called into service at any time the chief of police considers it necessary to have additional officers to preserve the peace and enforce the law. However, no person appointed to the reserve police force may carry a weapon or otherwise act as a peace officer until he has been approved by the chief of police and the city council, and has otherwise complied with the provisions of this article. After approval, he may carry a weapon only when authorized by the chief of police, and when discharging his official duties as a duly constituted police officer. Reserve police officers shall act only in a supplementary capacity to the regular police force and shall in no case assume the full-time duties of regular police officers, and then only after first complying with all requirements for such regular police officers. 
(Code 1962, § 18-43; Ord. No. 1971-16, Art. III, 9-7-1971) 
Sec. 62-54. - Compensation and benefits. 
    Members of the police reserve force shall serve without compensation from the city. However, the city council may, at its discretion, provide uniform compensation for the members thereof, when, in the opinion of the council, such service merits compensation. The compensation shall be based solely upon the time served by a member of the police reserve force while in training for or in the performance of official duties. Nothing in this section or in this article shall be construed to authorize or permit a member to become eligible for participation in any pension fund or other benefits created pursuant to state statute or city ordinances to which regular officers may become a member by payroll deduction, or otherwise. 
(Code 1962, § 18-44; Ord. No. 1971-16, Art. IV, 9-7-1971) 
Sec. 62-55. - Temporary appointment. 
    Any person serving as a reserve law enforcement officer before August 30, 1971, may be appointed to temporarily serve as a reserve law enforcement officer without fulfilling the minimum training standards established by the commission on law enforcement officer standards and education of the state. However, such service shall be limited to a period terminating January 1, 1973, unless such person has subsequently fulfilled the minimum physical, mental, educational, moral, and training standards established by the commission on law enforcement officers standards and education. 
(Code 1962, § 18-45; Ord. No. 1971-16, Art. V, 9-7-1971) 
Sec. 62-56. - Appointment. 
    No person shall be appointed to membership in the police reserve force without having first made written application therefor to the chief of police. Such application shall be made, under oath, on such forms and giving such information as the chief of police may require. Upon approval by the chief of police, such application shall be further approved by the mayor and the city council, and such action shall become a part of the official minutes of that body. Upon concurrence of the chief of police, the mayor and members of the city council, the appointment shall become effective. 
(Code 1962, § 18-46; Ord. No. 1971-16, Art. VI, 9-7-1971) 
Sec. 62-57. - Limitation as to number; terms of office; reprimand; suspension and discharge. 
    The city council may, from time to time, by resolution entered in its minutes, limit the number of members of the police reserve force. Such members shall hold their office at the will and pleasure and at the discretion of the city council and the chief of police. Should any member thereof prove himself incompetent to perform or discharge his duties, or refuse to conform to rules and regulations of the department, or in any manner so conduct himself whereby the department may be brought into ill repute, he shall, at the discretion of the chief of police, be subject to a reprimand, suspension, or discharge by such chief. Should any member so reprimanded, suspended, or discharged feel that he has been unfairly dealt with, he may, on written request, appeal to the city council for a review of the action. All appeals taken to the city council shall be in writing, signed by the applicant, and verified by his oath. Such writing shall state such facts as to enable the city council to evaluate the complaint, and the complaint shall be limited to the writings so verified. Such review shall be construed as a personnel matter and attendance shall be limited to the appellant, his witnesses, and other persons as the council may direct. 
(Code 1962, § 18-47; Ord. No. 1971-16, Art. VII, 9-7-1971) 
Chapter 66 - LIBRARY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Public library, § 13.13. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; civic and cultural affairs, ch. 26; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Library systems, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 441.121 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Failure to return library materials. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he intentionally or knowingly fails to return library materials to the Effie and Wilton Hebert Public Library, Port Neches, Texas, which were loaned to the actor or borrowed in the actor's name. 
(b)  The actor's intent and knowledge shall be presumed if: 
(1)  Pursuant to agreement, the library materials were to be returned on a date specified; 
(2)  Actual notice is given or notice in writing is sent by depositing in the United States mail the notice addressed to the actor at his address shown on the records of the library, stating that the library materials were not returned on the date specified; and 
(3)  The library material is not returned to the owner within 20 days of receipt of such notice. 
(c)  If notice is given in accordance with subsection (b)(2) of this section, it is presumed that the notice was received no later than five days after it was sent. 
(d)  In prosecution under this section, it is no defense that the actor, though the actual borrower, no longer possesses the library materials. 
(e)  In prosecution under this section, it is an affirmative defense that another borrowed the library material in the name of the actor, without his effective consent. 
(f)  An offense under this section is a class C misdemeanor, and any person who shall violate any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00. Each day of the continuance of such violation shall be considered a separate offense and each and every day shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Code 1962, § 14-12; Ord. No. 1978-10, §§ 1-6, 6-19-1978; Ord. No. 1998-05, § 1, 5-21-1998; Ord. No. 1998-24, § 1, 6-18-1998) 
Secs. 66-2-66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LIBRARY DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 66-31. - Established. 
    Pursuant to the Charter, a department is hereby created within the framework of the governmental organization of the city, which shall be known as the library department, and it shall function according to the laws of the state, the Charter and the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 2-49; Ord. No. 1975-13, § 1, 10-7-1975) 
Charter reference- Power to provide for and maintain public library, § 13.13. 
Sec. 66-32. - Acceptance of gifts. 
    The city hereby accepts all gifts and donations of books and equipment heretofore made for the Port Neches Public Library, which shall be known as the Effie and Wilton Hebert Public Library, with grateful thanks to the donors both of books and/or time, and such books and equipment, together with such additions as may be made from time to time, shall constitute and form the books and equipment of the Port Neches Public Library. 
(Code 1962, § 2-50; Ord. No. 1975-13, § 2, 10-7-1975; Ord. No. 1983-01, § 1, 1-20-1983) 
Sec. 66-33. - Library board of trustees. 
(a)  Established; powers and duties; absenteeism. 
(1)  There is hereby created the board of trustees of the Port Neches Public Library. Such board shall administer and supervise the operation of the Port Neches Public Library and any branches thereof as may be hereafter established by the council, under the supervision and control of the city manager. Such board may recommend to the city manager such rules and regulations as it shall deem necessary for the orderly use of the library facilities and in governing the performance of duties of the library employees and personnel, who will forward the rules and regulations to the city council for appropriate action. 
(2)  If any member of the board of trustees is absent for more than 50 percent of the meetings during any one year, such member shall be removed and replaced by the city council. 
(b)  Composition; term of members. The board of trustees shall consist of five members, to be appointed by the city council. Three shall be appointed during even-numbered years, and two shall be appointed during odd-numbered years, for two-year terms. 
(c)  Finances. The board of trustees shall have no power to obligate the city in any manner whatsoever. Its finances shall be handled in the same manner as any division of the city government. 
(Code 1962, §§ 2-51-2-53; Ord. No. 1975-13, §§ 3-5, 10-7-1975; Ord. No. 1978-02, § 1, 1-16-1978) 
Sec. 66-34. - Creation of Friends of the Library organization. 
    The library board of trustees shall have the power to create an organization known as the Friends of the Library, which shall consist of interested citizens in such numbers as the board of trustees shall deem appropriate from time to time, which the board of trustees may call upon for suggestions and support for the successful operation of the Port Neches Public Library. 
(Code 1962, § 2-54; Ord. No. 1975-13, § 6, 10-7-1975) 
Sec. 66-35. - Acceptance of designation of community library. 
    The city hereby accepts the designation of a community library as authorized by the state library and historical commission, pursuant to the authority invested in the commission by the Texas Library Systems Act (V.T.C.A., Government Code § 441.121 et seq.). 
(Code 1962, § 2-55; Ord. No. 1976-5, § 1, 5-18-1976) 
Sec. 66-36. - Membership in Houston Major Resource System. 
    Such community library as designated in section 66-35 shall be a member of the Houston Major Resource System. 
(Code 1962, § 2-56; Ord. No. 1976-5, § 1, 5-18-1976) 
Chapter 70 - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND TRAILERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 46; floods, ch. 54; health and sanitation, ch. 58; planning, ch. 90; solid waste, ch. 94; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; subdivisions, ch. 102; utilities, ch. 114; waterways, ch. 122; zoning, ch. 126. 
State Law reference- Manufactured Housing Standards Act, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 5221f. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME COACHES AND MOBILE HOME PARKS 

Sec. 70-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mobile home coach means a transportable single-family dwelling unit which is or may be mounted on wheels, suitable for yearround occupancy, and containing the same water supply, waste disposal and electrical conveniences as immobile housing. 
    Mobile home park A means a parcel of land under single ownership which has been planned and improved for the placement of mobile home coaches for transient use, supplementary structures and accessory uses not otherwise prohibited by this Code. 
    Mobile home park B means a parcel of land which is: 
(1)  Under multiple ownership or which may be developed under multiple ownership; 
(2)  Recorded in its entirety as a subdivision plat with the appropriate right-of-way dedications for streets, alleys and/or easements, lots and blocks; and 
(3)  For the placement of mobile home coaches for nontransient use, supplementary structures and accessory uses not prohibited by this Code. 
    Site plan means a line drawing clearly describing the mobile home park and its environs, which shall include adequate labeling and dimensioning of all fundamental features of the project, the legal description of the property, north point, and date, and shall be drawn to engineering scale. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-1; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 1, 4-7-1970) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-32. - Applicability of existing ordinances. 
    This article shall be cumulative of and in addition to all other ordinances of the city directed to the protection of the public health, safety and welfare and shall never be construed to have repealed any provision of any such ordinance by implication or to have affected any acts or proceeding undertaken by virtue of any such other ordinance. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-11; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 2, 4-7-1970) 
Sec. 70-33. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the building official, or his designated representative, to make inspections to determine the existence of violations of this article. A complete report of any violations discovered shall be made to the city manager for further handling. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-9; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 1, 4-7-1970) 
Sec. 70-34. - Enforcement. 
    In case any building, structure or mobile home coach is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained, or any building, structure, mobile home coach or land is used, in violation of section 70-41 or in violation of any applicable section of this Code, the city manager, in addition to other remedies, may institute any proper action or proceeding in the name of the city to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion, maintenance, or use, to restrain, correct or abate such violations, to prevent the occupancy of such building, structure, mobile home coach, or land, or to prevent any illegal act, conduct, business or use in or about such premises. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-10; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 1, 4-7-1970) 
Sec. 70-35. - Parking mobile home coach outside mobile home park. 
(a)  Parking on public street. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any mobile home coach on any street, highway, alley, sidewalk, or other public place in the city for a longer period than three hours. 
(b)  Parking in mobile home park required; exceptions. No mobile home coach shall be parked for use or occupancy on any tract of ground within the city limits except in a duly authorized mobile home park A or B, which shall be located in an S-5 zoning district; provided, however, that: 
(1)  The building official may permit the parking, use and occupancy of a mobile home coach outside a duly authorized mobile home park for a period of time not exceeding ten days, when such coach is occupied by persons employed in the operation of a temporary recreational, amusement or civic activity. Such temporary parking, use and occupancy of a mobile home coach shall be permitted only when the mobile home coach is parked on the same premises on which the activity is located and only when adequate sanitary facilities are available upon the premises for the use of the occupants of the mobile home coach. 
(2)  The city council may authorize permits for mobile homes outside duly authorized mobile home parks in special hardship cases. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-2; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 1, 4-7-1970; Ord. No. 1979-14, § 1, 7-2-1979) 
Sec. 70-36. - Mobile home park permit required; issuance; fee. 
    Prior to the issuance of a building permit by the building official, the city council shall approve a mobile home park permit, A or B type. Application for a permit shall be made in writing to the city manager, shall be signed, and shall contain the name and address of the applicant, the location and address of the mobile home park, and a legal description of the property to be used for the mobile home park, and shall be accompanied by a site plan and by the deposit of a fee of $150.00. The city council shall reserve the right to refuse to examine any incomplete, unintelligible or indefinite drawings or plans, and such proposed mobile home park type A or B plans shall conform to the minimum standards as set out in sections 70-39 and 70-40. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-3; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 1, 4-7-1970) 
Sec. 70-37. - Revocation of type A mobile home park permit. 
    A mobile home park permit type A, as issued by the city council, may be revoked or suspended by the building official for any period of time, after written notice to the permit holder and upon a determination by him that: 
(1)  The permit holder, an employer, or any employee of the permit holder has violated any provision of this article or any provision of this Code relating to mobile home parks, within 60 days immediately preceding the date of revocation. 
(2)  The permit holder or owner of the mobile home park for which the permit is issued is failing to comply and maintain the mobile home park in compliance with the requirements set forth in section 70-39 providing for certain minimum standards. 
(3)  The permit holder, an employer, or any employee of the permit holder has refused to allow the director of health or any of his inspectors, the building official or any of his inspectors, the chief of police, the chief of the fire department, or any of their authorized employees, or any other duly authorized employee of the city, to enter upon the mobile home park at all reasonable times for the purpose of inspecting the mobile home park for compliance with the provisions of this article and any other applicable city ordinance. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-8; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 1, 4-7-1970) 
Sec. 70-38. - Building permits. 
    No person shall erect or construct, or proceed with the erection or construction of, add to, enlarge, improve, alter, repair, convert, extend or demolish any mobile home park, type A or B, mobile home coach stand, building, structure, or fence, or any part thereof, or install any plumbing, electrical or mechanical equipment as a part of the site, building or structure, or make any other improvements to any mobile home coach lot A or B, or cause such work to be done, within a mobile home park type A or B without obtaining a building permit from the building official. The building permit shall be granted only after a permit for a type A or B mobile home park, as set out in section 70-36, has been granted by the city council and the mobile home park conforms to the permit approved and/or granted by the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-4; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 1, 4-7-1970) 
Sec. 70-39. - Standards for type A mobile home park. 
    Any mobile home park type A established, constructed, or erected, and, in the case of existing mobile home parks, that portion extended, altered, expanded and/or improved, shall conform to and comply with the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Park area. Each mobile home park shall provide a minimum of four acres in area, but in no case shall there be less than 15 mobile home coach lots. 
(2)  Density. Each mobile home park shall not exceed a maximum density of 15 mobile home coach lots per acre as determined by the total area bounded by the mobile home park property lines. 
(3)  Private streets. Private streets shall be provided and shall extend continuously from the public street right-of-way so as to provide suitable access to all mobile home coach lots and other facilities or uses permitted in the mobile home park as well as provide adequate connection to future streets at the boundaries of the mobile home coach property line. Private streets shall meet the following standards: 
a.  The minimum pavement width for private streets which provide direct access to five or more mobile home coach lots shall be 20 feet. 
b.  Private street intersections shall generally be at right angles. Offsets at intersections of less than 125 feet (centerline to centerline) shall be avoided. Intersections of more than two streets at one point shall be avoided. 
c.  Dead-end private streets shall be limited to a maximum length of 1,000 feet and shall be provided with a vehicular turning space, with a turning circle of 80 feet in diameter. 
d.  All private streets shall be provided with a smooth, hard, and dense surface, which shall be durable and well drained under normal use and weather conditions. The base must have at least six inches of compacted material with a double course of inverted penetration or two inches of hot-mix asphalt. 
e.  Private streets which may connect two public street rights-of-way shall, by the use of curves, offsets, location, and/or the use of two or more streets, be located so as to discourage through traffic. 
(4)  Mobile home coach lots. Each and every mobile home coach lot shall conform to the following standards: 
a.  Each lot shall be served with sanitary sewer, water, electrical power, telephone service, and natural gas. 
b.  Each lot shall provide an average minimum width of 35 feet and an average minimum depth of 75 feet, or 2,625 square feet. 
c.  Each lot shall abut and/or have access to a private street for a minimum distance of 12 feet. 
d.  Each lot shall provide a mobile home coach stand which shall provide an adequate foundation for the placement of one single-family mobile home coach. The mobile home coach stand shall be: 
1.  Impervious to plant material such as weeds, grass and shrubs. 
2.  A minimum of 11 feet in width and 50 feet in length. 
3.  Located not closer than three feet to the mobile home coach lot line, and be located at least ten feet from any private street, and be a minimum of five feet from the rear mobile home coach lot line (the end of the mobile home coach stand opposite the end adjacent to the private street). 
e.  No physical structure, dumpmaster, container, carport, cabana, awning, fence, or storage locker shall be permitted within ten feet of a private street, provided further the setbacks from the sides and rear shall be three feet, save and except a fence, from any mobile home coach lot line not adjacent to the private street. 
f.  Each lot shall provide a minimum of two off-street parking spaces. The spaces shall: 
1.  Have a permanent all-weather surface. 
2.  Have dimensions of not less than eight feet six inches by 18 feet zero inches, or 300 square feet. 
3.  Be accessible to an all-weather surfaced private street. 
4.  Be appropriately defined and marked. 
5.  Be so located and regulated that no parking, or maneuvering incidental to parking, shall be on any public street or walk. 
6.  Provide adequate barriers to keep any parked vehicle from extending into or overhanging any public dedicated street or private street. 
7.  Be so designed that any vehicle may be parked and unparked without requiring the moving of any other vehicle. 
g.  Double frontage of mobile home coach lots shall be avoided. 
h.  No vehicular access to a mobile home coach lot is permitted from a public dedicated street. 
(5)  Setbacks. 
a.  All mobile home coach stands and attached mobile home coaches shall be located as follows: 
1.  A minimum of 25 feet from any mobile home park property boundary line abutting upon a public dedicated street, and five feet from residentially used or zoned R-1 and R-2 property, as set out in this Code. 
2.  A minimum of five feet from any mobile home park property boundary line, not abutting upon a public dedicated street, when the abutting property is used or zoned as industrial or commercial property, provided further that a six-foot solid permanent fence or wall shall be constructed along the mobile home coach property boundary line. 
b.  All accessory uses shall be located a minimum of ten feet from any mobile home coach lot line. 
(6)  Drainage. The ground surface in all parts of every mobile home park shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe, efficient manner so as not to permit water to stand or become stagnant. 
(7)  Lighting. The private streets, parking lots, walks, and service areas shall be kept properly and adequately lighted at all times so the mobile home park shall be safe for occupants and visitors. All entrances and exits shall be lighted. 
(8)  Refuse pickup. A refuse pickup easement shall be granted by the owner of the mobile home park to the city if these facilities are located so as to require the entrance of a municipal vehicle into the mobile home park. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-5; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 1, 4-7-1970) 
Sec. 70-40. - Minimum standards for type B mobile home park. 
    A mobile home park type B, established, constructed, erected, extended, altered, expanded and/or improved, shall conform with the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Park area. Each mobile home park B shall provide a minimum of four acres in area. 
(2)  Layout; streets and blocks. Within a mobile home park B, no block shall be longer than 1,320 feet in length and streets shall be laid out to provide a minimum distance of 250 feet, center of street to center of street, between intersections. 
(3)  Mobile home coach lots. Each and every mobile home coach lot shall conform to the following standards: 
a.  Each lot shall be served with sanitary sewer, water, electrical power, telephone service, and natural gas. 
b.  Each lot shall provide for the placement of one single-family mobile home coach, with all garages, carports, enclosed rooms and porches being subordinate to this primary use. 
c.  No average dimension (width or depth) shall be less than 50 feet. 
d.  Each lot shall abut and/or have access to a public dedicated street for a minimum distance of 20 feet. 
e.  Each lot shall provide a minimum area of 5,400 square feet, determined by the lot lines. 
f.  Prior to occupancy of any mobile home coach lot, it must be provided with a mobile home stand or foundation for the placement of a single-family mobile home coach. The mobile home coach stand shall be impervious to plant material such as weeds, grass, and shrubs. The minimum size shall be the same size as the mobile home coach to be placed on the lot. The stand may be provided by either the developer or the owner. 
g.  Double frontage of mobile home coach lots shall be avoided. 
h.  No vehicular or pedestrian access to a mobile home coach lot is permitted from a public dedicated street not completely contained or located within the tract of land authorized as a mobile home park. No access to a mobile home coach lot is permitted except when the lot directly across the public street is located in the mobile home park and designated as and complying with the standards for a mobile home coach lot as provided in this section. 
i.  Each lot shall be officially recorded in a subdivision plat. 
(4)  Off-street parking. Off-street parking shall be provided at a minimum rate of two spaces for each mobile home coach lot, prior to occupancy of any mobile home coach. 
(5)  Setbacks. All mobile home coach stands and attached mobile home coaches and all other structures shall be located as follows: 
a.  A minimum of 15 feet from any mobile home park property or boundary line adjacent to a public dedicated street not providing access to the mobile home coach lot (fences are excluded). 
b.  A minimum of 20 feet from the front lot line. 
c.  A minimum of ten feet from the rear lot line. 
d.  A minimum of five feet from the side lot line. 
(6)  Public facilities; streetlights. Public facilities shall be provided as shown in chapter 102. Ornamental streetlight poles shall be provided by the developer in accordance with the city's policy at the time the mobile home subdivision is developed. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-6; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 1, 4-7-1970) 
Sec. 70-41. - Uses permitted in type A or B mobile home parks. 
    Upon issuance of a mobile home park permit, type A or B, by the city council, no use except the following shall be permitted in any mobile home park, type A or B: 
(1)  Single-family mobile home coaches. 
(2)  Accessory uses providing service to the occupants of the mobile home park. Such uses may include recreational facilities, central or community garages, storage buildings and washaterias. 
(3)  Supplementary structures. 
(Code 1962, § 12A-7; Ord. No. 1970-2, § 1, 4-7-1970) 
Chapter 74 - NATURAL RESOURCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 58; parks and recreation, ch. 82; planning, ch. 90; solid waste, ch. 94; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; subdivisions, ch. 102; utilities, ch. 114; waterways, ch. 122; zoning, ch. 126. 
State Law reference- Oil and gas, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code ch. 81 et seq.; authority of city to lease oil, gas or mineral land, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 253.005. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OIL, GAS AND OTHER MINERALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-31. - Enforcement of article. 
    It shall be the duty of the building official to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 9; Code 1962, § 15-3; Ord. No. 1999-15, § 5, 5-6-1999) 
Sec. 74-32. - Permit for exploration by use of explosives. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to do any exploration work for oil, gas or other minerals by the use of explosives within the city limits without first obtaining a permit therefor. 
(b)  Application. Any person desiring to make explorations for oil, gas or other minerals by the use of explosives shall make application to the oil and gas inspector for a permit required by subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Insurance. No permit shall be issued to any person to do exploration work for oil, gas or other minerals by the use of explosives within the city until the applicant submits to the oil and gas inspector sufficient evidence that such applicant is covered by liability insurance, in a sum not less than $1,000,000.00 per person, $10,000,000.00 per accident and $10,000,000.00 property damage, in the doing and performing of such exploration work. 
(d)  Fee. Each applicant for a permit required by subsection (a) of this section shall pay to the city a fee therefor of $1,500.00. 
(e)  Term. When a permit required by subsection (a) of this section is issued, it shall authorize the permittee to engage in the exploration work covered thereby for a period of 30 days. 
(Ord. of 1-20-1959, §§ 1-3; Code 1962, §§ 15-4-15-8; Ord. No. 1999-15, §§ 6, 7, 5-6-1999) 
Secs. 74-33-74-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OIL AND GAS WELLS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 74-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Lease means any tract of land subject to an oil, gas and mineral lease or other oil and gas development contract, or any unit composed of several tracts and leases but operated as one lease, and any tract of land in which the minerals are owned by an operator or someone holding under him, but which, due to the fee royalty ownership, is developed and operated as a separate tract. 
    Permittee means the person to whom is issued a permit for the drilling and operation of a well under this division, and his administrators, executors, heirs, successors and assigns. 
    Technical words or phrases. All technical or oil and gas industry words or phrases used in this division and not specifically defined in this section shall have that meaning customarily attributable thereto by prudent operators in the oil and gas industry. 
    Well means and includes any hole or bore to any sand, formation, strata or depth for the purpose of producing and recovering any oil or gas liquid hydrocarbon, or any of them. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 1; Code 1962, § 15-14) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-52. - Location in or obstruction of streets. 
    No well shall be drilled and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any location which is within any of the streets or alleys of the city, and no street or alley shall be blocked or encumbered or closed in any drilling or production operation, except by special permit by order of the city council, and then only temporarily. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 3; Code 1962, § 15-15) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 
Sec. 74-53. - Compliance with zoning restrictions; location near residence or commercial building. 
    No well shall be drilled and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any location that is not property zoned for such activity or which is nearer than 1,000 feet to any residence or commercial building, without the written permission of the owner of such residence or building. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 4; Code 1962, § 15-16; Ord. No. 1999-15, § 8, 5-6-1999) 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 126. 
Sec. 74-54. - Bond. 
(a)  Generally. If a permit is issued by the city council under the terms of this division for the drilling and operation of a well, no actual drilling operations shall be commenced until the permittee shall file with the city secretary a bond in such principal sum as is determined by the city council, not to be less than $1,000,000.00. Such bond shall be executed by a reliable insurance company authorized to do business in the state, as surety, and with the permittee as principal, and shall run to the city for the benefit of the city and all persons concerned. Such bond shall be conditioned that the permittee will comply with the terms and conditions of this division in the drilling and operating of the well. Such bond shall become effective on or before the date the bond is filed with the city secretary and remain in force and effect for at least a period of six months subsequent to the expiration of the term of the permit issued. In addition, the bond shall be conditioned that the permittee will promptly pay all fines, penalties and other assessments imposed upon the permittee by reason of his breach of any of the terms, provisions and conditions of this division, and that the permittee will promptly restore the streets and sidewalks and other property of the city which may be disturbed or damaged in the operations, to their former condition, and that the permittee will promptly clear all premises of all litter, trash, waste and other substances used, allowed or occurring in the drilling or producing operations, and will, after abandonment, grade, level and restore the property to the same surface condition, as nearly as possible, as existed when operations for the drilling of the well were first commenced, and that the permittee will be required to execute and deliver to the city an indemnity agreement in substantially the following form: 
HOLD HARMLESS AGREEMENT 
CITY OF PORT NECHES 
WHEREAS, ___________, A ___________ CORPORATION, has applied to drill or explore for oil and gas by   (describe project)   , as described in the application and drawings provided to the CITY OF PORT NECHES, TEXAS, by ___________ on the _____ day of _______, ___, reference to which is hereby made for all purposes; and,

CITY ATTORNEY  
(b)  New bond. If, at any time, the city council shall deem any permittee's bond to be insufficient for any reason, it may require the permittee to file a new bond. 
(c)  Reduction in amount. If, after completion of a well, the permittee has complied with all of the provisions of this division, such as removing derricks, clearing premises, etc., he may apply to the city council to have the bond reduced to a sum of not less than $500,000.00 for the remainder of the time the well produces without reworking. During reworking operations, the amount of the bond shall be increased to the original amount. 
(d)  Violation of conditions. It shall be unlawful for the principal of any bond filed in accord with this section to violate any condition of such bond. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, §§ 8, 31; Code 1962, § 15-17; Ord. No. 1999-15, §§ 9, 10, 5-6-1999) 
Sec. 74-55. - Insurance. 
(a)  Generally. In addition to the bond required by section 74-54, each permittee, prior to the commencement of any drilling operations, shall file with the city secretary a certificate of insurance showing that the permittee has in full force and effect a policy of standard comprehensive public liability insurance, including contractual liability covering bodily injuries and property damage, naming the permittee and the city, with an insurance company authorized to do business within the state. Such policy or policies in the aggregate shall provide for the following minimum coverage: 
(1)  Bodily injuries, $1,000,000.00 one person; $10,000,000.00 one accident. 
(2)  Property damage, $10,000,000.00. 
The permittee shall file with the city secretary certificates of such insurance as stated in this subsection, and shall obtain the written approval thereof by the mayor, who shall act thereon within ten days from the date of such filing. 
(b)  Cancellation. Such insurance policy shall not be cancelled without written notice to the city secretary at least ten days prior to the effective date of such cancellation. If the insurance policy is cancelled, the permit granted shall terminate and the permittee's rights to operate under the permit shall cease until the permittee files additional insurance as provided in this section. 
(c)  Reduction in amount. If, after completion of a well, the permittee has complied with all of the provisions of this division, such as removing derricks, clearing premises, etc., he may apply to the city council to have his insurance policies reduced as follows: 
(1)  Bodily injuries, $1,000,000.00 one person; $10,000,000.00 one accident; 
(2)  Property damage, $10,000,000.00; 
for the remainder of the time the well produces without reworking. During reworking operations, the amount of the insurance policy shall be increased to the original amount. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 8; Code 1962, § 15-18) 
Sec. 74-56. - Premises to be kept clean and sanitary. 
    The premises of every well shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, free from rubbish of every character, to the satisfaction of the health officer, at all times drilling operations or reworking operations are being conducted and as long thereafter as oil and/or gas is being produced therefrom. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 22; Code 1962, § 15-19) 
Sec. 74-57. - Watchman. 
    From the start of the erection of a derrick, mast or ginpole until the well is abandoned and plugged or completed as a producer and enclosed with a fence as provided in this division, the permittee shall keep a watchman on duty on the premises at all times. It shall not be necessary to keep an extra watchman on duty on the premises when other workers of the permittee are on the premises. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 12; Code 1962, § 15-20) 
Sec. 74-58. - Maximum depth. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drill a well within the city limits to a true vertical depth in excess of 12,000 feet, and no drilling and operating permit shall be granted for any well to a true vertical depth in excess of 12,000 feet. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 10; Code 1962, § 15-21) 
Sec. 74-59. - Derrick and rig. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or operate in connection with the drilling or reworking of any well within the city limits any wooden derrick or any steam-powered rig, and all engines shall be equipped with adequate mufflers approved by the oil and gas inspector. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to permit any drilling rig or derrick to remain on the premises or drilling site for a period longer than 60 days after completion or abandonment of the well. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 12; Code 1962, § 15-22) 
Sec. 74-60. - Pits. 
    Either earthen or steel slush pits shall be permitted in connection with the drilling operation. If a steel pit is used, the pit and its contents shall be removed from the premises and the drilling site within 30 days after completion of the well. If an earthen slush pit is used, the pit shall be filled and leveled within 120 days after completion of the well. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 13; Code 1962, § 15-23) 
Sec. 74-61. - Casing generally. 
(a)  All casing, including surface protection and production strings, shall be either seamless steel or equivalent quality oil well casing. Each production string of casing must comply with at least the following minimum internal pressure yield strength, computed in accordance with API standards:

(b)  Each joint and length of each particular casing string shall, prior to setting, unconditionally pass a complete cold water test. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 14; Code 1962, § 15-24) 
State Law reference- Casing, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code § 91.011. 
Sec. 74-62. - Setting and cementing casing. 
    No well shall be drilled within the city limits without properly setting the surface casing to a minimum depth of 800 feet. No well shall be drilled within the city limits without cementing the surface casing by the pump and plug method with sufficient cement to completely fill all of the annular space behind such casing to the surface of the ground, and without cementing the production string by the pump and plug method with sufficient cement to completely fill all the annular space behind the production string to at least 600 feet above the highest oil and/or gas bearing horizon, and, if a protection string of casing is required under the terms of this division, without cementing the protection string by the pump and plug method with sufficient cement to completely fill all the annular space behind the protection string to at least 600 feet above the highest oil and/or gas bearing horizon. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 15; Code 1962, § 15-25) 
Sec. 74-63. - Valves and blowout preventers. 
    No well shall be drilled within the city limits without properly equipping the surface casing, when set, with at least one master valve, and without properly equipping the protection casing, when set, with at least one master valve and one fluid-operated ram type blowout preventer, and without properly equipping the production casing during completion operations and workover operations with at least one master valve and at least one fluid-operated ram type blowout preventer. On each well drilled, a valve cock or kelly cock shall be installed on the kelly used. Each blowout preventer shall test 6,000 pounds and its mechanical operation shall be tested at least once every eight-hour period, and all control equipment shall be in good working condition and order at all times. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 16; Code 1962, § 15-26) 
Sec. 74-64. - Drilling fluid. 
(a)  No well shall be drilled within the city limits without using mud as the drilling fluid after the setting of surface casing as provided in section 74-62. Prior to the time the well reaches a total depth of 5,000 feet or the depth of the first known or encountered oil or gas bearing horizon, whichever is the lesser depth, the weight of the mud-laden drilling fluid shall be at all times maintained at not less than ten pounds per gallon. 
(b)  After the well reaches a total depth of 5,000 feet or the depth of the first known or encountered oil or gas bearing horizon, whichever is the lesser depth, the weight of the mud-laden drilling fluid shall be at all times maintained at such weight as will provide a hydrostatic head of not less than 500 pounds per square inch in excess of the formation pressure. In reworking a well, a drilling fluid shall be at all times maintained at such weight as will provide a hydrostatic head of not less than 500 pounds per square inch in excess of the formation pressure. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 17; Code 1962, § 15-27) 
Sec. 74-65. - Drill stem tests. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person connected with the drilling or reworking operations of any well within the city limits to take and to complete any drill stem test except during daylight hours, and then only if the well effluent during the test is produced through an adequate oil and gas separator to storage tanks and the effluent remaining in the drill pipe at the time the tool is closed is flushed to the surface by circulating drilling fluid down the annulus and up the drill pipe. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 18; Code 1962, § 15-28) 
Sec. 74-66. - Tubing. 
    All tubing used in any well within the city limits shall be seamless steel tubing having not less than a minimum internal pressure yield strength of 5,280 pounds per square inch if used in connection with a well completion at a depth not exceeding 7,000 feet, or less than a minimum internal pressure yield strength of 7,260 pounds per square inch if used in connection with a well completion at a depth in excess of 7,000 feet. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 19; Code 1962, § 15-29) 
Sec. 74-67. - Bradenheads. 
    Each well drilled within the city limits shall be equipped with a bradenhead with a working pressure of not less than 3,000 pounds per square inch. Bradenheads shall not be welded. The bradenhead installed on the surface casing shall be set above ground level and shall be equipped with fittings having a working pressure rating of not less than 3,000 pounds per square inch. The bradenhead pressure shall be checked at least once each calendar month and, if pressure is found to exist, proper remedial measures shall be immediately taken to eliminate the source and the existence of the pressure. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 20; Code 1962, § 15-30) 
Sec. 74-68. - Christmas tree and well head connections. 
    The Christmas tree and all well head connections on each well drilled within the city limits shall be as follows: On all flowing wells completed at a depth above 4,000 feet, the Christmas tree and well head connections shall have at least a minimum working pressure of 2,000 pounds per square inch and a minimum test pressure of at least 4,000 pounds per square inch; on all wells completed to a depth of from 4,001 to 7,000 feet, the Christmas tree and well head connections shall have at least a minimum working pressure of 3,000 pounds per square inch and a minimum test pressure of at least 6,000 pounds per square inch; and on all wells completed below a depth of 7,000 feet, the Christmas tree and well head connections shall have at least a minimum working pressure of 5,000 pounds per square inch and a minimum test pressure of at least 10,000 pounds per square inch. All piping and fittings connecting the well head to an oil gas separator shall have at least the same minimum working pressure and minimum test pressure as specified in this section for Christmas tree and well head connections. If the surface shut-in pressure of any well in the city limits exceeds 2,000 pounds per square inch, the flow wing of the Christmas tree shall be equipped with an automatic closing safety valve in addition to the regular control valves. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 21; Code 1962, § 15-31) 
Sec. 74-69. - Storage tanks and separators. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use, construct or operate, in connection with any producing well within the city limits, any crude oil storage tanks except to the extent of two steel tanks for oil storage, not exceeding 500 barrels' capacity each, and so constructed and maintained as to be vapor-tight, and each surrounded with an earthen firewall at such distance from the tanks as will, under any circumstances, hold and retain at least 11/2 times the maximum capacity of such tank. A permittee may use, construct and operate a steel conventional separator and such other steel tanks and appurtenances as are necessary for treating oil, with each of such facilities to be so constructed and maintained as to be vapor-tight. Each oil gas separator shall be equipped with both a regulation pressure relief safety valve and a bursting head. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 24; Code 1962, § 15-32) 
Sec. 74-70. - Fencing of well upon completion. 
    Any person who completes any well as a producer shall enclose the well, together with its surface facilities and storage tanks, by a substantial, smooth net wire fence sufficiently high and properly built so as to ordinarily keep persons and animals out of the enclosure, with all gates thereto to be kept locked when the permittee or his employees are not within the enclosure. In noncongested areas, the oil and gas inspector, in his discretion, may waive the requirement of any fence or may designate the type of fence to be erected. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 25; Code 1962, § 15-33) 
Sec. 74-71. - Motive power for post-drilling operations. 
    Motive power for all well operations after completion of drilling operations shall be electric or properly muffled gas, gasoline or diesel engines. Mufflers shall be approved by the oil and gas inspector prior to their use. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 23; Code 1962, § 15-34) 
Sec. 74-72. - Flaring and burning of escaping gas. 
    No person engaged in drilling or operating any well shall permit gas to escape or be vented into the air unless the gas is flared and burned. All gas flared or burned from a torch, pipe or any other burning device within the city limits must be flared or burned in such manner so as not to constitute a fire hazard to any property, and the location of the torch, pipe or other burning device and the construction, maintenance and operation thereof shall at all times be in full compliance with such regulations as may from time to time be issued by the oil and gas inspector. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 26; Code 1962, § 15-35) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50. 
Sec. 74-73. - Disposal of saltwater and other impurities. 
    The permittee shall make adequate provisions for the disposal of all saltwater or other impurities which he may bring to the surface, such disposal to be made in such manner as to not contaminate the water supply, present or prospective, or to injure surface vegetation. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 28; Code 1962, § 15-36) 
Sec. 74-74. - Abandonment. 
    Whenever any well is abandoned, it shall be the obligation of the permittee and the operator of the well to set a 200-foot cement plug in the bottom of the surface casing with the bottom of the plug 100 feet below the surface casing section and the top of the plug 100 feet above the surface casing section, and to set a 50-foot cement plug in the top of the surface casing. No surface or conductor string of casing may be pulled or removed from a well. During initial abandonment operations, it shall be the obligation of the permittee and the operator of the well to flood the well with mud-laden fluid weighing not less than ten pounds per gallon and the well shall be kept filled to the top with such mud-laden fluid at all times. Mud-laden fluid of the specifications stated in this subsection shall be left in the well bore below and between cement plugs. Any additional provisions or precautionary measures prescribed by the state or the railroad commission of the state in connection with the abandonment and plugging of a well shall be complied with by the permittee. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 27; Code 1962, § 15-37) 
State Law reference- Abandoned wells, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code ch. 89. 
Sec. 74-75. - Violation of federal or state regulations. 
    Any violation of the laws of the state or any rules, regulations or requirements of any state or federal regulatory body having jurisdiction in reference to drilling, completing, equipping, operating, producing, maintaining or abandoning an oil or gas well or related appurtenances, equipment or facilities, or in reference to firewalls, fire protection, blowout protection, safety protection or convenience of persons or property, shall also be a violation of this division and punishable as such. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 29; Code 1962, § 15-38) 
Secs. 74-76-74-90. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Permit to Drill or Operate 

Sec. 74-91. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person, acting either for himself or acting as agent, employee, independent contractor, or servant of any other person, to commence to drill, to drill or to operate any well within the city limits or to work upon or assist in any way in the prosecution or operation of any such well, without a permit for the drilling and operation of such well having first been issued by authority of the city council in accordance with the terms of this subdivision. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 2; Code 1962, § 15-44) 
Sec. 74-92. - Application. 
    Every application for a permit to drill and operate a well shall be in writing, signed by the applicant or by some person duly authorized to sign the application on his behalf, and filed with the city secretary. No application shall request a permit to drill more than one well. The application shall include full information, including the following: 
(1)  The date of the application. 
(2)  The name of the applicant. 
(3)  The address of the applicant. 
(4)  The proposed site of the well, including: 
a.  The name of the fee owner. 
b.  The name of the lease owner. 
c.  A brief description of the land. 
(5)  The type of derrick to be used. 
(6)  The proposed depth of the well. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 5; Code 1962, § 15-45) 
Sec. 74-93. - Fee. 
(a)  The fee for a permit required by this subdivision shall be $1,500.00, which amount, in cash, shall accompany the application. 
(b)  If any permit applied for under this subdivision is refused, or if the applicant notifies the city council, in writing, that he does not elect to accept the permit as tendered and wishes to withdraw his application, or if the bond of the applicant is not approved and the applicant notifies the city council, in writing, that he wishes to withdraw his application, then, upon the happening of such events, the fee filed with the application as provided in this section shall be returned to the applicant, except that there shall be retained therefrom by the city $500.00, as a processing fee. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, §§ 5, 6; Code 1962, § 15-46; Ord. No. 1999-15, § 12, 5-6-1999) 
Sec. 74-94. - Issuance; contents; effect. 
(a)  The city council, within 20 days after the filing of an application for a permit to drill and operate a well, shall determine whether or not the application complies in all respects with the provisions of this division; and, if it does, the council shall then fix amount of the principal of the bond and insurance provided for in sections 74-54 and 74-55 and, after such determination, shall issue a permit for the drilling and operation of the well applied for. Each permit issued shall: 
(1)  By reference have incorporated therein all the provisions of this division with the same force and effect as if this division were copied verbatim in the permit. 
(2)  Specify the well location with particularity as to lot number, block number, name of addition or subdivision, or other available correct legal description. 
(3)  Contain and specify that the term of such permit shall be for a period of one year from the date of the permit and as long thereafter as the permittee is engaged in drilling operations with no cessation of such operations for more than 90 days, or as long as oil or gas is produced in commercial quantities from the well drilled pursuant to such permit; provided that, if at any time after discovery of oil or gas the production thereof in commercial quantities shall cease, the term shall not terminate if the permittee commences additional reworking operations within 90 days thereafter, and if they result in the production of oil or gas, so long thereafter as oil or gas is produced in commercial quantities from the well. 
(4)  Contain and specify such conditions as are by this division authorized. 
(5)  Specify the total depth to which the well may be drilled, not exceeding the projected depth. 
(6)  Contain and specify that no actual operations shall be commenced until the permittee shall file and have approved an indemnity bond in the designated principal amount as so determined by the city council and conditioned as specified in section 74-54. 
(b)  A permit issued under this section shall be in duplicate originals and shall be signed by the mayor and, prior to delivery to the permittee, signed by the permittee (with one original to be retained by the city and one by the permittee). When so signed, such permit shall constitute the permittee's drilling and operating license and the contractual obligation of the permittee to comply with the terms of such permit, such bond and this division. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 6; Code 1962, § 15-47) 
Sec. 74-95. - Termination. 
    When a permit has been issued under this subdivision, the permit shall terminate and become inoperative without any action on the part of the city unless, within 90 days from the date of issuance, actual drilling of the well shall have commenced. The cessation for a like period of the drilling operations or the cessation of the production of oil or gas from the well after production shall have commenced shall operate to terminate and cancel the permit, and the well shall be considered as abandoned for all purposes of this division, and it shall be unlawful thereafter to continue the operation or drilling of such well without the issuance of another permit. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 7; Code 1962, § 15-48) 
Sec. 74-96. - Supplemental permit for deepening well. 
(a)  Once any well has either been completed as a producer or abandoned as a dry hole, it shall be unlawful for any person to drill such well to a deeper depth than that reached in the prior drilling operations unless the permittee as to such well obtains a supplemental permit after filing a supplemental application with the city secretary specifying: 
(1)  The then condition of the well and the casing therein. 
(2)  The depth to which it is proposed that such well be deepened, not to exceed in any event a total true vertical depth from the surface of 12,000 feet. 
(3)  The proposed casing program to be used in connection with the proposed deepening operations. 
(4)  Evidence of adequate current tests showing that the casing strings in the well currently pass the same tests as are in this division provided for in case of the drilling of the original well. 
(b)  If the city council is satisfied that the well may be deepened with the same degree of safety as existed in the original well, a supplemental permit may be issued, without an additional filing fee, to the permittee, authorizing the deepening and operation of the well to such specified depth as applied for, not exceeding in any event a total true vertical depth from the surface of 12,000 feet. In any deeper drilling or any deeper completion or any deeper production operations, the permittee shall comply with all other provisions contained in this division and applicable to the drilling, completion and operation of a well. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 11; Code 1962, § 15-49) 
Sec. 74-97. - Violation of provisions of permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any permittee to violate any of the provisions of his permit issued under this subdivision. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 31; Code 1962, § 15-50) 
Sec. 74-98. - Revocation. 
    The city council, at any regular or special session or meeting thereof, may, after ten days' notice has been given to the permittee that revocation is to be considered at such meeting, revoke or suspend any permit issued under this subdivision and under which drilling or producing operations are being conducted, if the permittee has violated any provision of the permit, his bond or this division. If the permit is revoked, the permittee may make application to the city council for a reissuance of such permit, and the action of the city council thereon shall be final. Revocation of any permit under this section shall be in addition to the penalties prescribed for the violation involved. 
(Ord. of 2-3-1959, § 31; Code 1962, § 15-51) 
Chapter 78 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1]
