(2)  To make plans and maps of the whole or any portion of the city and of lands outside the city limits located within the planning area of such city limits, and any other land outside the city which, in the opinion of the city planning commission, bears a relation to the planning of the city, and to make such changes in additions and extensions of plans or maps within the city as it deems such changes advisable. 
(3)  To aid and assist the city council in the preparation of the city budget and determination of sources of funds, and in procuring of financial and other aid and assistance for the city from the state and federal governments, and their agencies, for each and all of the purposes enumerated in this section. 
(4)  To act with and assist all other municipal and governmental agencies, and especially the city council, in formulating and executing proper plans for municipal development. 
(5)  To plan and recommend the location, plan and extent of city alleyways, parks, playgrounds, airports, automobile parking places, and other public grounds and public improvements, for the location and planning of public buildings, schools, and other properties, and of public utilities, including bus terminals, railroad depots and terminals, whether public or privately owned, for water, lights, sanitation, sewage disposal, drainage, flood control, transportation, communication and shipping facilities, and for the removal, relocation, widening, extension, narrowing, vacation, abandonment or change of use of any of such public places, work buildings, facilities or utilities. 
(6)  To select and recommend to the city council routes of streets, avenues and boulevards, and particularly to investigate and recommend the opening, widening, or abandonment of streets, avenues, boulevards and alleyways or the changing thereof to conform to the city's system, present and future, of all streets, avenues, boulevards, alleyways and parks. 
(7)  To investigate, consider and report to the city council on the layout and plan of any new subdivision in the city or property situated within the planning area, and to approve all plans, plats or replats of additions within the city limits or within the planning area. 
(8)  To recommend to the city council for adoption rules and regulations governing plats and subdivisions of land within the corporate limits of the city or within the planning area to promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the community and the safe and orderly and healthful development of the community. Such rules and regulations may be adopted by the city council only after a public hearing held thereon. 
(9)  To recommend plans to the city council for improving, developing, expanding and beautifying the parks, lakes and public buildings in or adjacent to the city and to cooperate with the city council and other agencies of the city in devising, establishing, locating, improving, selecting, expanding and maintaining the public parks, playgrounds and lakes for public recreation. 
(10)  To aid and assist the city council by recommending plans for the development of civic centers and to make investigations, consider and make recommendations to the city council concerning traffic regulations, routing and controlling and highway designations. 
(11)  To review the city's building codes and recommend any changes that may be desirable. 
(12)  To study, investigate and approve, or disapprove, all proposed amendments, supplements or changes in the boundaries of the districts zoned within the city and report its action to the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 2-26; Ord. No. 1963-8, § 3, 11-15-1963) 
Sec. 90-34. - Conflicts with zoning ordinance. 
    The provisions of this article shall be cumulative of the zoning ordinance passed by the city council on May 17, 1943, and subsequent amendments thereto, but should there exist any conflict between the provisions of the prior ordinances and this article, such conflicting provisions are hereby expressly repealed. 
(Code 1962, § 2-27; Ord. No. 1963-8, § 4, 11-15-1963) 
Chapter 94 - SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Garbage disposal, §§ 3.06(o), 13.15(c). 
Cross reference- Disposal of dead fowl, § 14-224; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 58; unsanitary, unsightly conditions on private premises, § 58-121 et seq.; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 70; natural resources, ch. 74; depositing stones, hard objects or rubbish in pool prohibited, § 82-77; utilities, ch. 114; fees for garbage collection service, § 114-6. 
State Law reference- Municipal powers relating to public health, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 122.006; minimum standards of sanitation and health protection measures, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 341.001 et seq.; local regulation of sanitation, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.001 et seq.; Solid Waste Disposal Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 361.001 et seq.; Solid Waste Resource Recovery Financing Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 362.001 et seq.; municipal solid waste, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 363.001 et seq.; litter, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 365.001 et seq. 

Sec. 94-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dry kitchen refuse means solid kitchen refuse after the liquid or slop has been drained off. 
    Kitchen garbage means dry kitchen refuse, all meat, vegetable and fruit refuse, small dead animals and dead fowl from any premises within the city limits. 
    Premises means business houses, boardinghouses, offices, theaters, hotels, restaurants, cafes, eating houses, tourist camps, apartments, sanitariums, roominghouses, schools, private residences, vacant lots and all other places within the city limits where garbage, trash or rubbish accumulates in ordinary quantities. 
    Quantities for one collection service means a quantity of 12 uncompacted yards, which will be measured by five full hopper loads from a rear loader garbage truck. 
    Receptacle means cans, plastic bags, dumpsters, boxes, sacks and bundles. 
    Rubbish means tin cans, bottles, glass, fiberglass, appliances, or scraps of iron, tin, wire or any other metals from any premises within the city limits. 
    Trash means paper of all kinds, rags, old clothing, paper containers, pieces of wood, boxes, barrels, crates, feathers, weeds and grass from any premises within the city limits. 
    Tree trimming contractor means any person who trims trees or similar bulky shrubbery on premises within the city limits in exchange for fees or other consideration. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, § 1; Code 1962, § 11-1; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967; Ord. No. 1999-26, § 1, 9-2-1999) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Accumulation and removal of garbage, refuse, etc., V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 341.013. 
Sec. 94-2. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate a provision of this chapter or fail to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Such person shall be punished within the limits and as provided by section 1-7. 
(Ord. No. 1999-26, § 11, 9-2-1999) 
Sec. 94-3. - Notice of violation. 
    Whenever the city determines that there has been a violation of this chapter or has grounds to believe that a violation has occurred, notice shall be given by certified mail describing the condition and section violated to the property owner. The notice shall state the prescribed time period to bring the violation into compliance. 
(Ord. No. 1999-26, § 10, 9-2-1999) 
Sec. 94-4. - Storage of waste; preparation of waste for collection. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning, managing, operating, leasing, or renting any premises to place dry kitchen refuse, kitchen garbage, rubbish or trash accumulated from such premises in such plastic bags, boxes, sacks, or other containers or bundles as the city council may from time to time, by resolution, prescribe. Such person shall also provide a suitable sanitary storage space for such accumulations prior to their delivery to the city for disposal purposes. The gross weight of any package or bundle shall not exceed 45 pounds in weight. Broken glass, cans, or any object having sharp edges shall be suitably wrapped or protected so as to prevent cutting or rupturing of the container in which it is placed. Tree limbs, for disposal, may be placed in such containers when the length thereof permits. If it is not expedient or not desirable to place the limbs in containers, then the limbs shall be cut into lengths not exceeding four feet and assembled into bundles and securely tied with a suitable binding, rope, card, or material. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942; Code 1962, § 11-3; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967; Ord. No. 1973-6, § 2, 7-3-1973; Ord. No. 1977-10, § 2, 4-19-1977; Ord. No. 1999-26, § 2, 9-2-1999) 
Sec. 94-5. - Placement of waste for collection; use of collection stations. 
    Garbage receptacles and limbs shall be placed at the edge of the street so as not to interfere with traffic, or at such other places as the director of public works shall, from time to time, direct. The city council may establish collection stations within the city where users of the city's garbage system may deliver for disposal by the city any refuse, garbage, rubbish, or trash, except those items described in section 94-16, provided the refuse, garbage, rubbish, or trash is placed in a plastic bag and properly tied. Any disposal of garbage at the collection center in any manner other than that outlined in this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor punishable under section 1-7. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, § 2; Code 1962, § 11-4; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967; Ord. No. 1977-10, § 3, 4-19-1977; Ord. No. 1999-26, § 3, 9-2-1999) 
Sec. 94-6. - Maintenance of receptacles. 
    Garbage receptacles shall be kept in sanitary condition and closed tightly, and lime must be used at places where receptacles for garbage, trash and rubbish are located to be collected by the garbage department to keep down odors and flies. The contents of all such receptacles shall be so protected that the wind cannot blow out and scatter the contents over the streets, alleys and premises of the city. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, § 14; Code 1962, § 11-5; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967; Ord. No. 1999-26, § 4, 9-2-1999) 
Sec. 94-7. - Interfering with receptacles or contents; unauthorized use of receptacles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the owner, occupant, or employees of the owner or occupant of the premises for which a dumpster or other receptacle or container has been furnished, or the duly authorized employees of the city, to handle, use or disturb the dumpster or other receptacle or container, or to handle or disturb the contents thereof, or to deposit garbage, trash and/or rubbish upon anyone's premises, other than their own, for collection by the city. 
(b)  No person shall meddle or interfere with any dumpster, garbage can or trash or rubbish receptacle or container, or in any way pilfer therefrom or scatter the contents thereof in any alley or street within the city. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, § 10; Code 1962, § 11-6; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967; Ord. No. 1981-13, § 1, 7-20-1981) 
Sec. 94-8. - Frequency of collection. 
    In the business district and from hotels, restaurants, cafes, boardinghouses, sanitariums and tourist camps, daily collections of garbage, trash and rubbish shall be made by the city, if necessary. In the residential districts, kitchen garbage, trash and rubbish shall be prepared for collection to be made two times per week. Tree limbs and small accumulations of scrap wood shall be prepared for one collection per week. The time of such collections shall be announced by the director of public works. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, § 15; Code 1962, § 11-7; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967; Ord. No. 1999-26, § 5, 9-2-1999) 
Sec. 94-9. - Charges for city collection service. 
    There shall be assessed and collected by the city for garbage collection services rendered by it such charges as are fixed from time to time by resolution of the city council and set out in section 114-6. 
(Code 1962, § 11-8; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967) 
Sec. 94-10. - Improperly placed or prepared material not to be collected by city. 
    The city garbage department will not make collection of kitchen garbage, trash or rubbish or tree limbs where such items are not prepared for collection and placed as designated by the terms of this chapter. Such failure to collect shall not relieve the person failing to comply with such provisions from prosecution for violating this chapter. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, § 7; Code 1962, § 11-9; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967) 
Sec. 94-11. - Use of private collection service. 
    The collection of garbage, trash and rubbish or of any kind of junk within the city limits by any person other than an employee of the garbage department is prohibited, except as provided for in sections 94-14, 94-15, 94-16 and 94-17. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, § 13; Code 1962, § 11-10; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967) 
Sec. 94-12. - Disposal of garbage, trash or rubbish within city limits prohibited. 
    The disposal of kitchen garbage, trash or rubbish in any place within the city limits is prohibited. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, § 9; Code 1962, § 11-11; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967) 
Sec. 94-13. - Placing waste in street or alley. 
    The placing of kitchen garbage, trash or rubbish or any article, thing or material in any street or alley in any manner other than as provided in this chapter is prohibited. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, § 8; Code 1962, § 11-12; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 
Sec. 94-14. - Disposal of waste from premises accumulating large quantity of waste. 
    Places of wholesale accumulations, such as killing and dressing plants for fowl, wholesale fruit and vegetable houses, storage houses and other places, where the daily accumulation of kitchen garbage, trash and rubbish is more than the ordinary quantities, are not included in the service furnished by the city garbage department, and the owners, occupants or other persons in charge of such places shall remove garbage, trash and rubbish therefrom, at their own expense, and in the manner and by the method directed by the director of public works. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, § 3; Code 1962, § 11-13; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967) 
Sec. 94-15. - Disposal of dead animals. 
    Heavy dead animals such as cows, horses and mules shall be delivered to the landfill at the expense of the owner or person having charge of the animal in the manner and by the method directed by the director of public works. The disposal of such animals within the city limits is hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, §§ 4, 9; Code 1962, § 11-14; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967; Ord. No. 1977-10, § 4, 4-19-1977; Ord. No. 1999-26, § 6, 9-2-1999) 
Sec. 94-16. - Disposal of bricks, trees, lumber and other heavy materials. 
    Heavy accumulations such as bricks, broken concrete, lumber, ashes, clinkers, cinders, dirt and plaster, sand or gravel, automobile frames, trees and other bulky, heavy material shall be disposed of at the expense of owner. The disposal of such material within the city limits is hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, §§ 5, 9; Code 1962, § 11-15; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967; Ord. No. 1999-26, § 7, 9-2-1999) 
Sec. 94-17. - Disposal of manure and waste oil. 
    Manure from cow lots, horse stables, poultry yards and pigeon lofts, and waste oils from garages or filling stations, shall be disposed of at the expense of the property owner. The disposal of such manure or waste oils within the city is hereby prohibited. 
(Ord. of 10-20-1942, §§ 6, 9; Code 1962, § 11-16; Ord. No. 1966-13, § 1, 2-21-1967; Ord. No. 1999-26, § 8, 9-2-1999) 
Sec. 94-18. - Disposal of tree and shrubbery trimmings. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every tree trimming contractor trimming or removing trees or similar bulky shrubbery within the city to have on file with the city a miscellaneous permit bond in the amount of $2,000.00. Prior to the start of such work, a separate permit for each premises shall be secured by the contractor. The contractor shall be responsible for the removal of all such material included in his contract with the property owner that exceeds the quantities included in one collection service. The homeowner's yard maintenance person responsible for regularly maintaining the yard, but rarely trimming a tree, shall be furnished the quantity of one city collection service for trash, per week. 
(b)  This section does not limit homeowners from performing such work themselves without the permit. Such material from the homeowner's work shall be placed for collection by the city as described in other sections of this chapter. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any homeowner or other person who trims trees, shrubbery or similar products on premises within the city limits to transport such material to other sites within the city not authorized by the city council. The city shall not collect any material from locations other than the property where the material was generated and for which the fees are paid. 
(Ord. No. 1999-26, § 9, 9-2-1999) 
Sec. 94-19. - Scavenging recyclable materials in residential areas. 
(a)  No person, other than the current resident of the property on which the items are placed, or an authorized carrier, shall remove, pick up, or transfer recyclable materials left at curbside in any residential subdivision, or at curbside at any single-family residence. Materials left at curbside in either specifically marked recovery containers or any other type of container are to be picked up by a designated carrier for the purpose of removal of recyclable materials. The materials referred to, to be left at curbside in specifically marked containers, will include recyclable materials included in the city's recycling program. 
(b)  Each removal of an item or items from a residential subdivision residence location or a single-family residence location shall constitute a separate violation of this section. Unauthorized persons removing materials or bins other than those persons designated in subsection (a) of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1962, § 11-19; Ord. No. 1991-02, § 1, 2-21-1991) 
Chapter 98 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Regulation of use of streets, § 2.01; official map, § 3.06(h); control of streets and public grounds, §§ 3.06(p), 13.05; franchises, art. X. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-8(6); any ordinance relating to municipal street maintenance agreements with the State of Texas saved from repeal, § 1-8(7); any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades for streets in the city saved from repeal, § 1-8(8); any ordinance relating to local improvements and assessments for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-8(11); consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages on street or sidewalk or in park, § 6-5; stalking livestock on street, § 14-31 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; numbering of buildings, § 18-351 et seq.; civic and cultural affairs, ch. 26; environment, ch. 46; floods, ch. 54; library, ch. 66; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 70; natural resources, ch. 74; location in or obstruction of streets of oil and gas wells, § 74-52; parks and recreation, ch. 82; planning, ch. 90; placing waste in street or alley, § 94-13; subdivisions, ch. 102; traffic and vehicles, ch. 110; operation of vehicles on one-way streets, § 110-31; driving in sidewalk area, § 110-34; stopping, standing and parking, § 110-121 et seq.; riding of bicycles on sidewalk, § 110-174; utilities, ch. 114; vehicles for hire, ch. 118; waterways, ch. 122; zoning, ch. 126. 
State Law reference- Municipal streets, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 311 et seq.; municipal charges for use of streets, etc., V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 182.025 et seq.; authority of city relative to streets and sidewalks generally, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 98-1. - Obstructions. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any junk, property, object or obstruction of any kind whatsoever under his control to be or remain in or upon any public street, or sidewalk, alley, easement or other public way, for longer than 24 hours or so as to obstruct or prevent the free use of an established public or private driveway or sidewalk, alley, easement or other public way, or entrance from such street into any public or private place or property. The police chief is authorized to order the removal of any property found in violation of this section at the owner's expense. 
(b)  Penalty. A violation of this section shall carry the penalty set forth in section 1-7. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, Art. 15, § 88; Code 1962, § 19-1; Ord. No. 1998-26, § 1, 6-18-1998) 
Sec. 98-2. - Inspection and repair of poles, pipes and other fixtures. 
    The city fire marshal, building official, electrical inspector, police officers and such other persons as may be designated by the city shall have the power and it shall be their privilege to examine and inspect, from time to time, all electric light poles, gas pipes and other fixtures in the streets, alleys and other public places within the city, for the purpose of seeing that all of such fixtures are in a safe and suitable condition, and, whenever any of them are found to be unsafe or unsuitable for the purpose for which they are used, the person using, possessing or maintaining the fixture shall be notified and required to place the fixture in a safe and suitable condition. 
(Ord. of 8-18-1941, § 11; Ord. of. 9-3-1941, § 11; Code 1962, § 19-3) 
Sec. 98-3. - Skating prohibited on sidewalks abutting portion of Port Neches Avenue. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use skates as a means of transportation on any sidewalk abutting Port Neches Avenue, between Dallas and Block Streets. 
(Ord. of 2-2-1937, § 2; Code 1962, § 19-4) 
Sec. 98-4. - Planting trees or shrubs in right-of-way. 
    Trees and shrubs shall not be planted in the street right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 1999-11, § 19-5(1), 4-1-1999) 
Sec. 98-5. - Maintenance of curbs; curb cuts. 
(a)  Curbs that become part of the driveway shall be maintained by the property owner. 
(b)  Curbs that are cut out for a driveway shall retain a 1 5/8 -inch rise to maintain the proper gutter drainage and shall be maintained by the property owner. Vehicles shall not be parked directly on top of a curb. 
(Ord. No. 1999-11, § 19-5(2), 4-1-1999) 
Sec. 98-6. - Sidewalk construction in class A subdivisions. 
    Sidewalks required for class A subdivisions shall be constructed by the developer or individual homeowner to the standards as outlined in chapter 102 or directed by the director of public works. To secure performance of this duty, the developer shall post a performance bond guaranteeing that the sidewalks will be completed within two years after the acceptance of the subdivision. 
    The performance bond shall be in an amount determined by the director of public works and shall be executed by the developer and appropriate corporate entity. 
    In lieu of the bond, an owner may deposit cash, a letter of credit issued by a federally insured financial institution, or other acceptable financial guarantee. If a letter of credit is used, it must list as the sole beneficiary the presiding officer of the city and be conditioned that the sidewalks be constructed or installed in compliance with the applicable state laws and city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1999-11, § 19-5(3), 4-1-1999; Ord. No. 2001-06, § 1, 5-30-2001; Ord. No. 2001-15, § 1, 11-1-2001) 
Sec. 98-7. - Inspection of sidewalk and curb construction. 
    Any construction on sidewalks or curbs shall require inspections by the proper city staff. 
(Ord. No. 1999-11, § 19-5(4), 4-1-1999) 
Sec. 98-8. - Painting on curbs, sidewalks and streets, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to paint, write or make any kind of mark, any signs or advertisement of any kind upon any sidewalk, curb or street of the city; except, however, commercial and residential street numbers may be painted on curbs; also excepted are markings associated with the location of utility lines or utilized in the performance of surveying; each marking shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2001-03, § 1, 3-1-01) 
Secs. 98-9-98-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLES, PIPES AND OTHER FIXTURES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 98-31-98-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RENTAL CHARGES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to fix compensation to be paid for use of city streets and alleys by utility companies, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1175(2). 

Sec. 98-51. - Violations; penalty. 
(a)  Failure to pay charge. Any person who shall operate any business without the payment of the rental provided for in this division shall be subject to a fine of up to $500.00 for each and every day that such person shall conduct such business using or occupying the streets, easements, alleys or other public ways of the city without the payment of such rental, which sum may be recovered by the city in a court of competent jurisdiction by a suit filed therein. 
(b)  Other violations. Every person, and the local manager or agent of every such person, failing or refusing to make the report required by section 98-53 or failing or refusing to allow the examination provided for in section 98-54 shall, upon conviction, be fined up to $500.00, and every day's failure or refusal as mentioned in this subsection shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 8-18-1941, §§ 9, 10; Ord. of 9-3-1941, §§ 9, 10; Code 1962, § 19-19; Ord. No. 1998-26, § 2, 6-18-1998) 
Sec. 98-52. - Charge imposed; amount; payment. 
    Every person occupying or using the streets, alleys and other public ways of the city with electric poles, pipes or other fixtures or with gas pipes or fixtures shall, as a condition to such further occupancy, pay to the city an annual rental charge equal to two percent of the gross receipts received by such person from his business conducted within the corporate limits of the city. Such charge shall be paid on or before August 1 of each year, based on the gross receipts during the preceding year ending June 30. 
(Ord. of 8-18-1941, § 3; Ord. of 9-3-1941, § 3; Code 1962, § 19-11) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to make reasonable charge, not exceeding two percent of gross receipts, for use of its streets, alleys, etc., by public utilities, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 182.025. 
Sec. 98-53. - Report of gross receipts. 
    All persons using or maintaining any electric light poles, pipes or other fixtures or gas pipes or fixtures in any of the streets, highways, easements, alleys, parks or other places within the corporate limits of the city shall, on or before August 1 of each year, file with the city secretary a sworn report showing the gross receipts from the business conducted by such person within the corporate limits of the city for the preceding year ending June 30. 
(Ord. of 8-18-1941, § 1; Ord. of 9-3-1941, § 1; Code 1962, § 19-12) 
Sec. 98-54. - Examination of records. 
    The city council may, when it sees fit, have the books and records of the persons rendering the statement required in section 98-53 examined by a representative of the city to ascertain whether such statements are accurate, but nothing in section shall be construed to prevent the city from ascertaining the facts by any other method. 
(Ord. of 8-18-1941, § 2; Ord. of 9-3-1941, § 2; Code 1962, § 19-13) 
Sec. 98-55. - Receipt for payment. 
    Upon receipt of the rental charge imposed by this division by the city, the city secretary shall deliver to the person paying the charge a receipt therefor, which receipt shall authorize such person to use and occupy the streets, alleys and public ways of the city in carrying on its business for 12 months from August 1 of such year. 
(Ord. of 8-18-1941, § 4; Ord. of 9-3-1941, § 4; Code 1962, § 19-14) 
Sec. 98-56. - Charge does not constitute tax; charge additional to taxes. 
    The rental charge imposed by this division is not charged as a tax but is made for the privilege now enjoyed and to be enjoyed by the persons upon whom it is imposed of using the streets, easements, alleys and other public ways of the city in the conduct of their businesses, and such charge is additional to all ad valorem and franchise taxes and to all taxes of every nature whatsoever imposed against such persons. 
(Ord. of 8-18-1941, § 5; Ord. of 9-3-1941, § 5; Code 1962, § 19-15) 
Sec. 98-57. - Applicability of other laws. 
    Nothing in this division is intended to relieve any person of any condition, restriction or requirement imposed by any law or ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. of 8-18-1941, § 6; Ord. of 9-3-1941, § 6; Code 1962, § 19-16) 
Sec. 98-58. - Limitation on rights granted; cancellation of privileges. 
    This division does not grant a franchise to any utility or person to use the streets, easements, alleys and other public ways, and shall never be so construed by a court or otherwise, and the city reserves the right to cancel the privileges granted under this division and refund the unearned rentals paid to the city. 
(Ord. of 8-18-1941, § 7; Ord. of 9-3-1941, § 7; Code 1962, § 19-17) 
Sec. 98-59. - Authority to adopt additional regulations. 
    The city hereby reserves the right to put into effect at any time other reasonable restrictions and regulations as to the erection and maintenance of poles, wires, pipes and other appurtenances in the streets, easements, alleys and other public ways of the city and to require such poles, wires, pipes and other property, equipment and fixtures as it may deem proper to be removed and to require wires to be run in conduits and pipes to be laid on such terms as the city may deem proper. 
(Ord. of 8-18-1941, § 8; Ord. of 9-3-1941, § 8; Code 1962, § 19-18) 
Secs. 98-60-98-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PIPELINES 

Sec. 98-81. - Violations; penalty; additional remedies. 
    Any person who shall violate or fail or refuse to comply with any of the provisions of this division, or of any permit issued under this division, or fail to comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereof in violation of this division, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each such person or agent shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of this division is committed or continued, and upon conviction of any such violation such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00. In addition, the city may, at its option, revoke any permit granted under this division, or any pipeline constructed without a permit, and order the immediate removal of the pipeline or pipeline system which is not constructed or maintained in accordance with the applicable safety standards. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-10; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 10, 6-1-1971) 
Sec. 98-82. - Permit required for installation. 
    No new pipeline for the transportation of crude petroleum, natural or other gas, or any liquid product or byproduct derived from crude petroleum or gas, or any explosive or lethal substance (referred to in this division as "products") shall be laid or installed within the corporate limits of the city without first securing a permit from the city council through its city manager or his representatives. This permit shall be required of all pipelines with the exceptions noted in this division for construction of natural gas pipelines under franchise agreement to serve the city, or for such industries as tank farms, petroleum refineries or chemical plants that pay city taxes under contract. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-1; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 1, 6-1-1971) 
Sec. 98-83. - Consultation with city prior to construction; approval of plans; application fee. 
    The applicant for a permit under this division shall consult with the city manager or his representatives far enough in advance of the planned construction that the city may acquaint the applicant with planned development of the city which shall be considered by the applicant and any other information that would benefit the applicant in avoiding difficulties with construction. The applicant shall submit the final detailed construction plans at least 30 days prior to the expected commencement of construction, and no construction shall commence until approved by the city council. Each such application shall be accompanied by an application permit fee of $1,000.00 to cover the administrative expenses of processing the application. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-2; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 2, 6-1-1971; Ord. No. 1981-07, § 1, 3-2-1981; Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, 3-3-2005) 
Sec. 98-84. - Issuance of permit. 
    The city council, on the recommendation of the city manager and the city's consulting engineer, will then consider approval of the application for a permit under this division, giving due regard to the pipeline's effect on the safety of the city. The following criteria will be used in determining the issuance of the permit: proximity to inhabited structures, materials to be transported, danger of pollution to city facilities, interference with city facilities, routings adjacent and parallel to existing pipelines, vertical and horizontal clearances, securing of rights-of-way, and protection of the city by means of a bond and insurance during construction, and adequate insurance or hold harmless agreements after construction. Such permit shall only be issued after the council has been satisfied of the safety of its citizens and that the applicant has agreed to pay the city for all present costs to the city and any other costs that may be indicated at a later date and a suitable fee for the use of any streets, alleys, public places, rights-of-way, etc., owned by the city. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-3; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 3, 6-1-1971) 
Sec. 98-85. - Bond, insurance and indemnity agreement required. 
    Any person making an application for a permit under this division for construction of a pipeline shall furnish a bond and insurance as may be required by the council before the permit shall be valid. Such person shall also furnish a hold harmless agreement indemnifying the city for any liability arising out of, or connected with, the construction, maintenance or operation of such pipeline by reason of the granting of such permit by the city council. The form of the hold harmless agreement, the bond or surety, and the insurance must meet with the approval of the city attorney. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-4; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 4, 6-1-1971) 
Sec. 98-86. - Exemptions from permit, bond and insurance requirements; submission of maps generally. 
(a)  Pipelines used in chemical plants, petroleum refineries or tank farms are generally exempt from the permit requirements and bond and insurance requirements of this division, provided such pipelines are used in operation of such chemical plants, oil refineries or tank farms and that they are wholly contained on property owned in fee by such corporation, individual or firm. Such firm, individual or corporation shall furnish the city a plat of the property, drawn to a suitable scale, showing the description of such property with metes and bounds, angles, distances and all pertinent data. Such plat shall also show the location of all other pipelines and equipment not owned 100 percent by the reporting firm, corporation or individual. Such information shall include descriptions of any easements on the reporting property showing an exact description of the easements and indicating if the easement is in fee, in perpetuity, or for a fixed period of time, along with the name and address of the individual, corporation or firm holding such easement. The size and depth of the lines and the use to which the easement has been placed, or the use contemplated, shall also be shown. 
(b)  Each individual, corporation or company shall furnish the city a plat, map or diagram showing the rights-of-way, the location of the proposed or existing pipeline and the type of easement for each pipeline or group of pipelines within the same rights-of-way, outside of plant or tank farm sites within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-5; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 5, 6-1-1971) 
Sec. 98-87. - Submission of maps by franchise holders. 
    Where a firm, corporation or individual holds a franchise from the city, the firm, individual or corporation shall furnish a map of its gas lines, stations, valves and regulators. This map shall include all lines with working pressures of 30 psi or over, and all lines of a size of two inches ID or more, regardless of the working pressure. These maps shall show the locations and depths on all public streets, alleys, public places, etc., or on individual private property, if such line is not laid on such property for the exclusive service of such property. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-6; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 6, 6-1-1971) 
Sec. 98-88. - Minimum operational requirements; reporting of accidents. 
(a)  All pipelines, except those described in section 98-86, are required to furnish a hold harmless agreement and insurance as described in section 98-85. If these pipelines do not meet the minimum requirements of the Department of Transportation, DOT, title 49, CFR 195 (Transportation of Liquids by Pipeline), and DOT title 49, CFR 192 (Transportation of Natural and Other Gas by Pipeline), or any subsequent amendment thereto, the corporation, firm or individual maintaining or operating the pipeline shall notify the city within 30 days after the enactment of Ordinance No. 1971-8 and shall present plans for approval to bring these lines up to these minimum standards within 90 days after the enactment of Ordinance No. 1971-8, and shall proceed with due diligence to perform the necessary repairs or maintenance after receiving the necessary approval required as for a new pipeline as described in section 98-83. It shall be unlawful for any corporation, firm or individual to maintain or operate a pipeline that does not meet the minimum requirements of this section. 
(b)  DOT, part 195, subpart B, stipulates a method of reporting certain accidents. When such accidents occur, the obligation to the city will be fulfilled by immediately notifying the police and/or fire department of the city, if their assistance is needed, and later by furnishing a copy of the written report prepared for the federal administrator. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-7; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 7, 6-1-1971) 
Sec. 98-89. - Affidavit of compliance with minimum safety standards. 
    The owners or operators of each pipeline operating inside the city limits, and not exempt by reason of sections 98-86 and 98-87, shall furnish an affidavit approved in form by the city attorney when paying taxes each year that the pipelines have met, and continue to meet, the minimum safety standards required in section 98-88. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-8; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 8, 6-1-1971) 
Sec. 98-90. - Marking of location of pipeline. 
    The owner of any pipeline within the city for the transportation of products described in section 98-82 shall, as required by the city, indicate by proper markers on the ground the location of any such pipeline. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-9; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 9, 6-1-1971) 
Sec. 98-91. - Applicability of federal and state regulations. 
    The provisions of this division shall be subject to any federal and state legislation, rules and regulations enacted or adopted, or which shall be hereafter enacted or adopted, to the extent that such laws and regulations shall preempt or supersede the authority of the city with respect to this division or any provision of this division. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-11; Ord. No. 1971-8, § 11, 6-1-1971) 
Sec. 98-92. - Relocation of pipelines. 
    If the city or its duly authorized representative shall elect to alter, construct or change the grade of any street, alley or other public way, any person subject to the terms of this division, upon reasonable notice by the city, shall remove, re-lay and relocate his pipelines, poles, wires, cables, underground conduit, manholes and other fixtures at his own expense. 
(Code 1962, § 16A-12; Ord. No. 1978-21, § 1, 12-4-1978) 
Chapter 99 - STREETS-MANAGEMENT OF THE RIGHT-OF-WAY 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 99-1. - Definitions. 
    Applicant means any user or potential user who desires to own, operate, maintain, and/or install facilities in City of Port Neches right-of-way. 
    Facility or facilities means any utility infrastructure including, but not limited to, pipes, wires, conduits, utility poles, and related appurtenances, situated within City of Port Neches right-of-way which are owned, operated, maintained, and/or installed by users other than the City of Port Neches. 
    Person means a designated representative of a user. 
    Street or public way or public right-of-way or public rights-of-way or rights-of-way or right-of-way means the surface of and the space above and below a public street, road, highway, freeway, land, path, public way or place, alley, court, boulevard, parkway, drive, or other easement now or hereafter held by or under the control of the city, to which the city holds the property rights in regard to the use for utilities. 
    User means any business, firm, corporation, entity, owner, and/or operator, other than the City of Port Neches, which owns, operates, maintains, and/or installs facilities within the City of Port Neches right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-2. - Criminal penalties. 
(1)  Any violation or failure to abide by, and comply with, any provision or requirement of this chapter shall be a violation and shall be punishable as a class "C" misdemeanor, subject to a fine of up to $500.00 per occurrence. 
(2)  Each day upon which there exists a violation of this chapter or a failure to abide by or comply with any provision or requirement of this chapter shall constitute a separate occurrence and shall subject the offender to separate criminal penalties. 
(3)  Prosecution pursuant to this chapter is in addition to and does not supplant other remedies. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-3. - Civil penalties. 
(1)  Civil penalties may be imposed for the violation for any provision of this chapter as follows: 
(a)  Up to $1,000.00 for each violation, and each day of a continuing violation may be considered a new violation; and/or 
(b)  If applicable, default and revocation of any or all permits granted to allow work in the rights-of-way, subject to the procedural guidelines noted in this chapter and any agreement which applies to the right-of-way user, and further subject to any limitations imposed by federal or state law. 
(2)  In imposing the penalties and the amount, the city may weight all applicable factors, such as damages caused by the violation, reasons for the violation, the seriousness of the violation, and all other factors. 
(3)  Monetary civil penalties may be imposed in the manner prescribed by either local or state law. 
(4)  In addition, the city council may order specific performance of any actions required by this chapter or required by a franchise, license or permit, including the permit authorizing work to be performed in the right-of-way, or any other agreement or authorization. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Secs. 99-4-99-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 99-11. - Right-of-way construction. 
(1)  No user shall commence or continue with the construction, installation or maintenance of facilities within the right-of-way in the city except as provided by the ordinances of the city and the directives of the public works department. 
(2)  No user shall be permitted to "cut" or excavate a street when it is otherwise possible to perform the construction or installation without disturbing the roadway surface. The director of public works shall determine whether to allow excavation based upon the justification submitted by the person desiring to perform such work. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-12. - Registration and construction permits. 
(1)  In order to protect the public health, safety and welfare, all users of the right-of-way will register with the City of Port Neches. Registration and permits will be issued in the name of the owner of the facilities. Registration must be renewed by January 15 of every year. Should, however, a user of right-of-way have a current and valid franchise agreement with the city, registration shall not be required as long as the franchise agreement remains in effect. When any information provided for the registration changes, the user will inform the City of Port Neches no more than 30 working days after the date the change is made. Registration shall include: 
(a)  The name of the owner of the facilities located within the right-of-way; 
(b)  The name of the user of the right-of-way; 
(c)  The name, address and telephone number of the people who will be contact person(s) for the user; 
(d)  The name(s) and telephone number of an emergency contact who shall be available 24 hours a day; 
(e)  Proof of insurance and bonds to include: 
1.  An applicant must provide proof of liability insurance in the amount of $6,000,000.00; $1,000,000.00 primary plus $5,000,000.00 umbrella. 
2.  The coverage must be on an occurrence basis and must include coverage for personal injury, contractual liability, premises liability, medical damages, underground, explosion and collapse hazards. 
3.  Each policy must include a cancellation provision in which the insurance company is required to notify the city in writing not fewer than 30 working days before canceling, failing to renew, or reducing policy limits. 
4.  The applicant shall file the required original certificate of insurance. The certificate shall state the policy number; name of the insurance company; name and address of the agent or authorized representative of the insurance company; name, address and telephone number of the insured; policy expiration date; and specific coverage amounts. 
5.  The city will accept letters and/or certificates of self-insurance which provide the same coverage as required herein. The city shall be notified in writing not fewer than 30 working days prior to any modification of the terms and/or conditions stipulated in the letter and/or certificate. 
(2)  Construction permits. 
(a)  Unless waived by the director of public works, no person shall perform any construction or installation of facilities in the right-of-way without first obtaining a construction permit, except as provided herein. The permit will be in the name of the person and/or entity which will own the facilities to be constructed. The permit application must be completed and signed by a representative of the owner of the facilities to be constructed. Emergency responses related to existing facilities may be undertaken without first obtaining a permit; however, the city shall be contacted by telephone, at a number furnished by the city, and the public works department shall be notified in writing at least three business days of any construction related to an emergency response; including a reasonably detailed description of the work performed in the right-of-way and an updated map of any facilities that were moved. This requirement shall be waived in the event of an ongoing, large-scale emergency situation as a result or any man-made or natural occurrence which alters or interrupts the normal use of the user's service to its customers. 
(b)  The permit shall state to whom it is issued, the location of work, the location of facilities, dates and times that work is to take place and any other conditions set out by the director of public works or his/her designee. 
(c)  The person (applicant) requesting a permit will provide the director of public works or his/her designee with documentation in the format specified by the city describing: 
1.  The proposed, approximate location and route of all facilities to be constructed, repaired, moved or installed and the applicant's plan for right-of-way construction; and the estimated construction time. 
2.  Engineering plans which will be on a scale of one inch to 50 feet unless otherwise approved by the director of public works. 
3.  Details of the location of all right-of-way and utility easements which applicants plan to use. 
4.  Detail of all existing city utilities and, to the extent known, other facilities in the right-of-way in relationship to applicant's proposed route. 
5.  Detail of what applicant proposes to install, such as pipe size, number of interducts, valves, etc. 
6.  Detail of plans to remove and replace asphalt and/or concrete in the street and/or right-of-way in accordance with the design improvement standards of the city. 
7.  Drawings of any bores, trenches, handholes, manholes, switch gear, transformers, pedestals, etc., including depth. 
8.  Handhole and/or manhole typicals of type of manholes and/or handholes applicant plans to use or access. 
9.  Complete legend of drawings submitted by the applicant. 
10.  Two sets of engineering plans must be submitted with permit application. 
11.  The name, address and phone numbers of the contractor or subcontractor who will perform the actual construction, including the name and telephone number of an individual with the contractor who will be available at all times during construction. 
12.  The construction and installation methods to be employed for the protection of existing structures, fixtures, and facilities within or adjacent to the right-of-way, and the dates and times work will occur, all of which (methods, dates, times, etc.) are subject to approval of the public works director or his/her designee. 
13.  Proof of insurance, bond or other required financial information is current and on file. 
(d)  All construction and installation in the right-of-way shall be in accordance with the permit for the facilities. The director of public works or his/her designee shall be provided access to the work and to such further information as he or she may reasonably require to ensure compliance with the permit. 
(e)  A copy of the construction permit and approved engineering plans shall be maintained at the construction site and made available for inspection by the director of public works or his/her designee at all times when construction or installation work is occurring. 
(f)  All authorize construction or installation work must be completed in the time specified in the construction permit. If the work cannot be completed in the specified time period, the applicant may request an extension in writing from the director of public works or his/her designee. The work that was authorized under the permit may continue while the request for an extension is pending. 
(g)  A copy of any permit or approval issued by federal or state authorities for work in federal or state right-of-way located in the city. 
(h)  A request for a permit must be submitted at least three working days before the commencement of work proposed in the request for review and approval, unless waived by the director of public works or his/her designee. 
(i)  Requests for permits will be approved or disapproved by the director of public works or his/her designee within a reasonable time of receiving all the necessary information. The director of public works or his/her designee will use his/her best efforts to approve or disapprove a request for a construction permit as soon as possible. 
(j)  The director of public works may request a preconstruction meeting with the applicant and their construction contractor. 
(j)  Valid permits are required for all construction whether new, replacement, or upgrading of the company's network facilities in the right-of-way, either aerial or underground. 
(l)  The utility, as a condition of the permit, shall be required to enter into a hold harmless agreement, the form of which will be provided by the city, and shall contain the indemnity provisions generally set out in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 283.057. 
(m)  Restoration of right-of-way must be made to a condition which puts the right-of-way back in substantially the same condition as prior to the commencement of the work. Such restoration shall be guaranteed through one full year after the completion of construction. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002; Ord. No. 2002-11, § 1, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 99-13. - Construction standards. 
(1)  The department of public works shall be notified 24 hours in advance that construction is ready to proceed by either the right-of-way user, their contractor, or representative. 
(2)  All construction shall be in conformance with all city codes and applicable local, state and federal laws. 
(3)  Advance warning signs, markers, cones and barricades must be in place before work begins in accordance with the current edition of the manual on uniform traffic control devices in place at the time a permit is requested. 
(4)  Applicant may be required to show proof of TNRCC-approved plans relating to stormwater and erosion when applicable or a letter stating that they are not required to obtain such plans. 
(5)  Lane closures on major thoroughfares will be limited to between 8:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. unless the director of public works grants prior approval. 
(6)  Without affecting applicant's authority to pursue liability against its contractors, applicants are responsible for the workmanship and any damages by contractors or subcontractors. A responsible representative of the applicant will be available to the public works department at all times during construction. 
(7)  Applicant or contractor or subcontractor will notify the public works department immediately of any damage to other utilities, either city- or privately-owned. 
(8)  Installed facilities must not interfere with city utilities, in particular gravity-dependent facilities. 
(9)  New nonmunicipal, nonelectric utilities must be installed at a minimum of two feet depth, unless a lesser depth is approved by the director of public works. New electric utilities must be installed at a minimum of three feet depth, unless a lesser depth is approved by the director of public works. 
(10)  All directional boring shall have the locator place bore marks and depths while bore is in progress. Locator shall place mark at each stem with paint dot and depth at least every other stem. 
(11)  Working hours in the rights-of-way are 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. Work that needs to be performed after 6:00 p.m. Monday through Friday or on Saturday must be approved by the director of public works in advance. Directional boring is permitted only Monday through Friday, 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. No work in the right-of-way shall be performed, except for emergencies, on Sunday or city holidays. 
(12)  Contractors working for applicant are responsible for obtaining line locates from all affected utilities prior to any excavation. 
(13)  Applicant will be responsible for verifying the location, both horizontally and vertically, of all affected facilities whether by potholing or hand digging prior to any excavation or boring with the exception of work involving lane closures. 
(14)  Placement of all manholes and/or hand holes must be approved in advance by the director of public works. 
(15)  No construction or installation work will be initiated unless a construction permit has been obtained from the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-14. - "Plan of record" plans. 
(1)  Right-of-way users must provide the director of public works or his/her designee with "plans of record" (also called "as-built" plans) within ten working days of completion of facilities in the right-of-way. Users who have facilities in the right-of-way existing as of the date of this chapter, and who have not provided "plans of record" shall do so not later than 120 working days after the passage of this chapter [March 21, 2002] when available. The plans shall be provided to the city in the format specified by the director of public works or his/her designee and with as much detail and accuracy as required thereby. All the criteria specified for plans submitted for the initial permit will be required for the "plans of record." Submittal of "plans of record" shall be in digital formatting as well as written or in any other format requested by the city. 
(2)  If the release of the location of any utilities or of plans of record submitted under this section would jeopardize public safety, the information shall be considered confidential. In addition, if plans of record submitted under this section include information expressly designated by the right-of-way user as a trade secret or other confidential information protected from disclosure by state law, the city may not disclose that information to the publication without the consent of the right-of-way user, unless otherwise compelled by an opinion of the attorney general pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, as amended, or by a court having jurisdiction of the matter pursuant to applicable law. This subsection may not be construed to authorize a right-of-way user to designate all matters in its plans of record as confidential or as trade secrets. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-15. - Conformance with public improvements. 
    Whenever by reasons of widening or straightening of streets, water or sewer line projects (e.g. install or improve storm drains, water lines, sewer lines, etc.), it shall be deemed necessary by the city council to remove, alter, change, adapt, or conform the underground or overhead facilities of a right-of-way user, such alterations shall be made by the owner of the facilities at its expense within 90 working days from receipt of notice to make the alterations, unless a different schedule has been approved by the director of public works or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-16. - Improperly installed facilities. 
(1)  Any person doing work in the city right-of-way shall properly install, repair, upgrade and maintain city facilities as determined by the director of public works. In the event that such work is not acceptable to the director of public works, such person shall be notified in writing by the director of public works and be granted ten working days to correct the unsatisfactory work. Should, however, the unacceptable work be deemed an immediate threat to health and safety by the director of public works, such person shall be notified verbally by the director of public works for immediate corrective action by such person. 
(2)  Facilities shall be considered to be improperly installed, repaired, upgraded or maintained if: 
(a)  The installation, repairs, upgrade or maintenance endangers people or property; 
(b)  The facilities do not meet applicable city codes; 
(c)  The facilities are not capable of being located using standard practices; 
(d)  The facilities are not located in the proper place in accordance with the directions provided by the public works department; or 
(e)  The facilities are placed in an area that interferes with city-owned facilities, including but not limited to, water or sewer lines or streets. Noncity-owned facilities shall be considered to interfere with city-owned facilities if he noncity-owned facility is within three feet horizontally of the city-owned facility, or the distance required by the permit, whichever is greater. Nothing in this section shall diminish the authority of the director of public works to direct the specific placement of specific lines. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-17. - Type of facilities. 
(1)  The director of public works shall approve the location of underground facilities. 
(2)  When poles are used, location and depth shall be subject to the approval of the director of public works as it pertains to possible conflicts with the city's infrastructure. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-18. - Restoration of property. 
(1)  Users of the right-of-way shall reasonably restore property affected by the construction of facilities to a condition that is equal to or better than the condition of the property prior to the performance of the work. 
(2)  Restoration must be to the reasonable satisfaction of the director of public works and shall not be considered complete until approved by the director of public works. The restoration shall include, but not be limited to: 
(a)  Installation of all manholes and handholes, as required; 
(b)  Backfilling all bore pits, potholes, trenches or any other holes. All such excavations shall be filled in daily, unless other safety requirements are approved by the director of public works; 
(c)  Leveling of all trenches and backhoe lines; 
(d)  Restoration of excavation site to city specifications including compacting, grading, and appropriate fill material; 
(e)  All locate flags shall be removed during the cleanup process by the applicant or his/her contractor at the completion of the work; 
(f)  Restoration must be made in a timely manner as specified by approved schedules and to the satisfaction of the director of public works or his/her designee. If restoration is not satisfactory and/or performed in a timely manner, all work in progress, including all work previously permitted but not completed, will be immediately halted and additional permits shall not be approved until all restoration is complete. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-19. - Revocation or denial of permit. 
    If any provision of this chapter is not followed, a permit may be revoked by the director of public works or his/her designee. If a person has not followed the terms and conditions of this chapter in work done pursuant to a prior permit, new permits may be denied or additional terms required. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-20. - Bill, recovery for damages. 
    Should any user of city right-of-way damage any city infrastructure located within the city right-of-way, the city may submit a bill for damages to the applicable user and seek recovery for all such damage. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 2, 3-21-2002) 
Sec. 99-21. - Franchise to prevail. 
    To the extent that this chapter is in express conflict with the terms and conditions of an existing and valid franchise agreement, the franchise agreement shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 2002-04, § 3, 3-21-2002) 
Chapter 102 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city saved from repeal, § 1-8(13); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 46; floods, ch. 54; flood hazard reduction standards for subdivision proposals, § 54-83; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 70; natural resources, ch. 74; planning, ch. 90; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; utilities, ch. 114; waterways, ch. 122; zoning, ch. 126. 
State Law reference- Platting and recording subdivisions or additions, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 212; extension of rules to extraterritorial jurisdiction, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.003. 

Sec. 102-1. - Applicability of chapter. 
    This chapter shall govern every person owning any tract of land within the city limits who may hereafter divide the tract of land into two or more parts for the purpose of laying out any subdivision of any tract of land or any addition to the city, or for laying out suburban lots or building lots, or any lots, streets, alleys, parks or other portions intended for the public use, or the use of purchasers or owners of lots fronting thereon or adjacent thereto. 
(Code 1962, § 20-1; Ord. No. 1972-14, § 1, 11-7-1972) 
Sec. 102-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Plat means a map or chart of the subdivision. It shall include the terms "plan," "plat" and "replat," in both singular and plural. 
    Resubdivision means the division of an existing subdivision, together with any change of lot size therein, or with the relocation of any street lines. 
    Subdivision means the division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more parts or lots for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale or building development or transfer of ownership, and shall include resubdivision. 
(Code 1962, § 20-2(2), (3), (5); Ord. No. 1972-14, § 2, 11-7-1972) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 102-3. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating this chapter or any portion thereof shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00, and each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable accordingly. 
(Code 1962, § 20-12; Ord. No. 1972-14, § 12, 11-7-1972; Ord. No. 1999-12, § 14, 4-1-1999) 
Sec. 102-4. - Policy; approval of subdivisions required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or the agent of any owner of land to lay out, subdivide, plat or replat any land into lots, blocks and streets within the city without the approval of the city council. It shall also be unlawful for any such owner or agent to offer for sale or sell property therein or thereby which has not been laid out, subdivided, platted or replatted with the approval of the city council. 
(b)  The city hereby defines its policy to be that the city will withhold all city improvements of whatever nature, including the maintenance of streets and the furnishing of sewer facilities and water service, from all additions and subdivisions, the platting of which has not been approved by the city council. 
(c)  No street number and no building permit shall be issued for the erection of any building in the city on any piece of property other than an original or a resubdivided lot in a duly approved and recorded subdivision without the written approval of the planning commission. 
(d)  The attention of each subdivider is directed to V.T.C.A., Property Code § 12.022, which states, in part: 
"(a)  The county clerk or a deputy of the clerk with whom a plat or replat of a subdivision of real property is filed for recording shall determine whether the plat or replat is required by law to be approved by a county or municipal authority or both. The clerk or deputy may not record a plat or replat requiring approval unless it is approved as provided by law by the appropriate authority and unless the plat or replat has attached to it the documents required by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.0105 or 232.0035, if applicable. If a plat or replat does not indicate whether land covered by the plat or replat is in the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the municipality, the county clerk may require the person filing the plat or replat for recording to file with the clerk an affidavit stating that information. 
"(b)  A person may not file for record or have recorded in the county clerk's office a plat or replat of a subdivision of real property unless it is approved as provided by law by the appropriate authority and unless the plat or replat has attached to it the documents required by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.0105 or 232.0035, if applicable." 
(e)  The building official may approve an amended plat to relocate one or more lot lines between one or more adjacent lots if: 
(1)  The owners of all affected lots join in the application for amending the plat; 
(2)  The amendment does not attempt to remove recorded covenants or restrictions; and 
(3)  The amendment does not increase the number of lots. 
(Code 1962, § 20-3; Ord. No. 1972-14, § 3, 11-7-1972; Ord. No. 1998-40, § 1, 9-17-1998) 
Sec. 102-5. - General requirements. 
    General requirements for subdivisions are as follows: 
(1)  Streets. Streets in general must conform to the following: 
a.  The minimum width shall be 60 feet; however, a greater width may be required. Streets that have no outlet shall end with a minimum 50-foot turnaround radius. 
b.  Streets shall connect with existing streets in adjoining subdivisions. 
c.  Streets shall be named to provide continuity with existing streets. 
d.  Streets shall be platted with appropriate regard for all topographical features lending themselves to attractive treatment and layout of utilities. 
(2)  Minimum width of alleys. Alleys, if provided, shall have a minimum width of 25 feet. 
(3)  Size of residential lots. Except as provided in the city zoning ordinance, chapter 126, exclusive of section 126.4.1, R-SF Residential-Single Family, residential lots shall be a minimum of 60 feet wide at the front or rear building line, whichever is less, and a minimum of 110 feet deep and, in no case, shall contain less than 6,600 square feet, exclusive of drainage easements. 
(Code 1962, § 20-4; Ord. No. 1972-14, § 4, 11-7-1972; Ord. No. 1977-8, § 1, 3-15-1977; Ord. No. 1999-12, § 1, 4-1-1999; Ord. No. 2007-16, § I, 11-1-2007) 
Sec. 102-6. - Monuments, benchmarks and lot markers. 
(a)  Monuments, consisting of one-half-inch iron pipe or larger, 24 inches in length, shall be placed at all corners of the block lines, the point of intersection of curves and tangents of subdivisions. 
(b)  One benchmark for each five acres of property or fraction thereof shall be permanently installed in an approved manner, with their location and the elevation shown on the plat. 
(c)  Lot markers shall be metal or concrete stakes, at least 24 inches in length, placed at each corner of all lots, flush with the average ground elevation, or they may be countersunk if necessary to avoid being disturbed. 
(Code 1962, § 20-5; Ord. No. 1972-14, § 5, 11-7-1972) 
Sec. 102-7. - Minimum improvements for class A subdivisions. 
    The minimum improvements for a class A subdivision shall be as follows: 
(1)  Streets. 
a.  Streets shall be constructed on six inches of six percent by weight of lime-treated subbase unless tests determine otherwise. Subgrades shall be accurately shaped, and any unstable subgrade is to be carefully stabilized by the addition of approved material in its place before placing base material. Lime-treated subbase shall be compacted to 95 percent standard AASHTO density. The sub-base shall be extended to a point two feet beyond the back of curb or edge of pavement. 
b.  Street pavement shall be of reinforced 3,000 psi within 28 days concrete, a minimum thickness of six inches, reinforced with six-inch by six-inch by six-inch gauge mesh or its equivalent (one-quarter-inch steel bar on 12-inch center or #4 bar on 24-inch center). Bars and mesh shall remain at a two-inch clearance from the subbase by chair-type supports. Streets shall have a width of 28 feet from back side of curb to back side of curb and have a six-inch stand-up reinforced curb. Expansion joints shall be provided at approximately 60-foot intervals with expansion joints also placed at all structures and at the curb return at street intersections. Material for expansion joints shall be redwood or equal. Contraction joints shall have an approximate spacing of 15-foot intervals. Longitudinal construction joints shall be at the centerline of the 28-foot pavement. All joints shall be sealed with a urethane sealant or proved equal. 
(2)  Sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be of 3,000 psi concrete, four inches thick and 42 inches wide, reinforced with six-inch by six-inch gauge mesh. Sidewalks shall be placed five feet from the back side of the curb and shall not circumvent without the approval of the director of public works. Sidewalks are required for all property which fronts or is adjacent to a road right-of-way, or as directed by the director of public works. 
(3)  Water mains. Water mains shall be a minimum of six inches or of sufficient size to supply residences with adequate domestic needs and fire protection. Water mains shall be C-900 class 150 PVC pipe or ductile iron pressure pipe class 350. Water mains shall be designed as a looped system with fire hydrants placed every 400 feet of roadway, or as approved by the fire chief. Water mains shall not be placed under the required sidewalk. Water mains shall be bedded in sand. All pipe, types of joints, joint materials, fittings, valves, fire hydrants, and bedding, and the installation thereof, shall comply with current AWWA specifications and concur with and be approved by the director of public works. 
(4)  Sewer mains. Sanitary sewer mains shall be of sufficient size and number to remove waste from the subdivision; however, the minimum size shall be eight inches in diameter. Sewer pipe shall be PVC SDR 26 ASTMD sewer pipe 3034. Pre-made sewer taps shall be required for all lots. Taps shall be made with wye fittings. A six-inch riser at the property line shall be used for the service of two lots. All risers shall be visible from above grade for the preservation of the survey pin. Sewer mains shall not be placed under the required sidewalk. Sewer mains shall be bedded in sand. All pipe, fittings, bedding and installations shall concur with and be approved by the director of public works. 
(5)  State approval of water and sewer facilities. Water and sewer facilities shall be approved by the state natural resources conservation commission or its designated state agency. 
(6)  Gutters. Gutter gradients shall be a minimum of 0.3 percent for straight runs and 0.6 percent for radii and turns. Inlet spacing shall be in accordance with recommendations for drainage. All storm sewer mains shall be ASTM C76 class III reinforced concrete pipe, except for special cases where permission, in writing, is obtained from the director of public works. 
(7)  Water, sewer and drainage easements; streetlights. Water, sewer and drainage utilities shall be designed to be placed in the street right-of-way. Where both water and sewer utilities are on the same side of the street, a ten-foot easement shall be required adjacent to the right-of-way line to obtain required spacing. Electrical, telephone and cable television utilities shall be placed in the rear of lots. Gas utility mains shall be placed as far as practicable from the city's water, sewer and drainage utilities. At all times, there shall be a minimum two-foot separation between the gas mains and city utilities. Easements shall be provided which are at least 15 feet wide in the rear of lots. Streetlight circuits require a minimum three-foot-wide easement from the rear of lots to the street where it is necessary for location of the light. Streetlights shall be provided and shall be mounted on ornamental poles, either concrete or metal. Lights shall be placed at a minimum of 200 feet and a maximum of 250 feet apart. Special priority conditions such as intersections, curves or bridges may justify a closer spacing. 
(Code 1962, § 20-6(1); Ord. No. 1972-14, § 6, 11-7-1972; Ord. No. 1999-12, § 2, 4-1-1999) 
Sec. 102-8. - Payment of costs of improvements; testing and inspection of improvements. 
(a)  Payment of costs generally. The subdivider shall pay all costs for providing the subdivision or resubdivision with streets, water, sanitary sewers, and storm sewers in accordance with the requirements for the type of subdivision or resubdivision the subdivider wishes to develop, and in accordance with the plans and specifications for such improvements. 
(b)  Payment of costs for subdivisions receiving reimbursement from city. In those subdivisions receiving reimbursement from the city, the contractor shall present approved plans and specifications for proposed improvements to the city council, and the city council shall advertise for bids, receive bids, and award the contract, assisted by the subdivider, for proposed work. Payment to the contractor for work performed shall be made from funds established by the subdivider for partial and final payment, which payment shall be initialled in accordance with controls and conditions established by the city manager. All final payments shall be approved by the city council. 
(c)  Tests. Tests of various materials, workmanship and function of improvements provided by the subdivider shall be subject to the following tests, which may be varied as directed by the city manager in writing. The objective of the outlined tests is to establish quality standards for facilities which become the property of the city. Generally, all materials shall be inspected and tested prior to placing of materials. Inspections and tests shall be performed by a city-designated laboratory at no cost to the city. 
(1)  Streets and sidewalks. The streets and sidewalks test shall consist of quality control for concrete and a density test when required by the director of public works. Concrete streets, sidewalks and curbs and gutters shall be constructed using an approved five-sack, 3,000 psi concrete. During placing of concrete, a minimum of three test cylinders shall be made and tested for each 80 cubic yards of concrete placed. Usually, when quantities do not meet the 80-cubic-yard amount, test cylinders shall be made and tested as required and directed by the director of public works. Prior to final acceptance by the city, cores shall be drilled and tested. A core shall be drilled and tested for each 1,000 square yards of pavement and sidewalk to establish proper thickness and strength. Tests shall be performed without cost to the city. 
(2)  Water mains. Water mains shall be tested hydrostatically and evaluation of leakage made from time and pressure as follows: (i) 100 psi test for 24 hours, (ii) 125 psi test for 16 hours, or (iii) 150 psi test for eight hours, the high (150 psi) test being preferred. Bacteriological tests shall be performed with city assistance in accordance with state department of health requirements. Tests shall be performed without cost to the city. 
(3)  Sanitary sewers. Sanitary sewer lines shall be tested for infiltration as directed by the director of public works. Air tests, hydrostatic tests, etc., shall be performed in accordance with current test standards without cost to the city. The city reserves the right to evaluate quality standards from data developed from information obtained by televiewing lines. If the city chooses to use this method, the city will pay for the television survey. 
(d)  Inspections; certification of compliance. All installations of approved improvements shall be inspected for compliance with city standards during construction under the city manager, the director of public works, and their selected professional registered engineer.
