After completion of improvements, the subdivider's engineer shall certify that improvements have been made in accordance with his plans and specifications, and/or modifications thereto, and request inspection and approval of the facilities by the city manager, the director of public works, the city engineer and their representatives. Upon inspection and approval of the facilities by the city manager, the director of public works and the city's professional engineer and the receipt of the certificate from the subdivider's engineer, the subdivision shall be presented to the council for final acceptance. 
(Code 1962, § 20-7; Ord. No. 1972-14, § 7, 11-7-1972; Ord. No. 1977-8, §§ 2, 3, 3-15-1977; Ord. No. 1999-12, § 4, 4-1-1999) 
Sec. 102-9. - Procedure for plat approval. 
(a)  Submission of preliminary plat; review by planning and zoning commission. Twenty-one copies of a preliminary plat shall be submitted to the director of public works for review by the city staff and a registered professional engineer appointed by the city 21 days prior to the monthly deadline to be presented to the planning and zoning commission, with a copy of the preliminary plat, along with the recommendations of the city staff and engineer, going to each member of the planning and zoning commission. The planning and zoning commission shall make its comments and recommendations to the city council, and the councilmembers shall each receive a copy of the preliminary plat, along with the recommendations, three days before the approval of the preliminary plat is to be submitted to the city council. The plat shall be drawn to a scale of 200 feet to one inch or longer, and shall show or be accompanied by the following information: 
(1)  The name of the subdivision shall be indicated. 
(2)  The names of the owner and the engineer or surveyor responsible for the survey and design shall be indicated. 
(3)  Boundary lines, existing building lines, and width and location of platted streets and alleys within and adjacent to the property shall be indicated. 
(4)  The width and depth and/or area of proposed lots shall be indicated. 
(5)  The physical features of the property shall be shown, including the location of water sources, culverts, bridges, proposed drainage ditches, including the total drainage area, showing inlets, and drainage calculations demonstrating that off-site downstream drainage facilities can accept increased runoff to DD7 facilities, present structures, easements, maintenance access easements with all necessary structural restrictions, streets and alleys, highways, etc., including widths and names. Streets, alleys, lot lines, etc., in adjacent subdivisions shall be shown dotted. All necessary data to reproduce the plat on the ground must be shown on the plat. 
(6)  A designation of the proposed uses of land within the subdivision shall be included. 
(7)  Adequate off-street parking must be provided for lots set aside or planned for business, public or institutional use. 
(8)  A map on a smaller scale must be presented to show the adjacent property or tracts and/or the nearest subdivision in the vicinity, and how the streets, alleys or highways in the subdivision submitted may connect with those nearby. 
(9)  Profiles of streets and ditches may be called for. 
(10)  In subdividing property, due consideration shall be given to suitable sites for schools, and to the dedication of parks and playgrounds. Such provision should be indicated on the preliminary plat in order that it may be determined when and in what manner such areas will be dedicated to the public use. Such property shall not be of a less desirable nature than other property in the subdivision. 
(11)  A letter from the appropriate independent school district shall be included stating that provisions for the site of future schools, if such be required, are adequate, or, if not required, then such letter shall so state. 
(b)  Action on preliminary plat by council; effect of approval. 
(1)  Following a review of the preliminary plat and negotiations with the subdivider on changes deemed advisable and the kind and extent of improvements to be made by him, the city council shall, within 30 days, act thereon as submitted, or modified, and, if approved, shall express its approval as "Conditional Approval" and state the conditions of such approval, if any, or if disapproved shall express its disapproval and the reasons therefor. 
(2)  The action of the city council shall be noted on three copies of the preliminary plat, and any conditions of either approval or disapproval shall be attached to and/or referred to each plat. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider, one copy shall be retained by the city council and the third copy shall be retained by the director of public works. 
(3)  Approval of the preliminary plat does not constitute acceptance of the subdivision, but is merely authority to proceed with the preparation of the final or record plat. No work shall be done on the subdivision before the final plat is accepted. Approval of a preliminary plat expires at the end of 90 days unless a final or record plat has been submitted to the city council. If changes by the city council, city manager and director of public works require submission of another preliminary plat, the city shall notify the subdivider, outlining changes desired or required for requested approval. 
(c)  Submission of final or record plat. Twenty-one blue line, white print copies of the final or record plat, with a reproducible tracing of the final plat, shall be submitted to the city council after the preliminary plat has been approved by the city manager, the director of public works and a registered professional engineer selected by the city and all changes and alterations made. No final plat will be considered unless a preliminary plat has been submitted first. Such plats shall be filed with the director of public works for review by the city staff and a registered professional engineer appointed by the city at least 21 days prior to the planning and zoning commission's monthly agenda deadline. The final plat shall show or be accompanied by the following data: 
(1)  Plats shall be drawn upon sheets 24 by 36 inches, to the scale of 100 feet to the inch. 
(2)  A title, including the name of subdivision, the owners, and the licensed land surveyor or registered engineer or registered public surveyor responsible for the plat, and the scale and location of the subdivision with reference to original land grants or surveys, and the date and north point, shall be included. 
(3)  The certificate of the registered engineer or licensed surveyor who surveyed, mapped and monumented the land shall be placed on the face of the plat. 
(4)  A certificate of ownership and dedication of all streets, easements, alleys, parks and playgrounds to public use forever, signed and acknowledged before a notary public by the owner and lienholder of the land, shall be submitted. 
(5)  An accurate on-the-ground boundary survey of the property shall be included, with bearings and distances and showing the lines of all adjacent land, streets, easements, maintenance access easements with all necessary structural restrictions, and alleys, with their names and width. Streets, alleys, lot lines, etc., in adjacent subdivisions shall be shown dotted. All necessary data to reproduce the plat on the ground must be shown on the plat. 
(6)  A certificate of approval to be signed by the members of the city council shall be placed on the face of the plat. 
(7)  Two sets of plans and specifications for water, sewers, paving, and drainage prepared by a registered engineer shall be submitted, which must be approved by the city council, and when appropriate by state or other agencies, prior to the beginning of any construction of the subdivision. 
(8)  A letter from the appropriate drainage commission addressed to the city council stating that plans for drainage of the subdivision are approved by the drainage commission shall be submitted. 
(9)  A letter from the servicing utility companies stating that the plat includes the easements required by them in the furnishing of utilities to this and future subdivisions shall be submitted. 
(10)  Two copies of deed restrictions shall be submitted. 
(11)  Funds for payment to the contractor for interim and final payment for work performed shall be submitted. 
(d)  Action on final plat by council. 
(1)  Following a review of the final plat, and when, to the satisfaction of the city manager and the director of public works, all conditions and requirements have been met, the city council shall approve the plat. 
(2)  Should the final plat, as submitted, fail to meet the conditions and requirements of the city manager and the director of public works, then the city council shall disapprove the plat and note its disapproval thereon, and attach thereto a statement of the reasons for disapproval. 
(3)  Approval or disapproval of the final plat shall be voted by the city council within 30 days after submission of the final plat. 
(4)  Upon approval of the final plat by the city council, the city shall retain the mylar and dedication deed with restrictions until all improvements are installed and the council accepts the subdivision. The developer shall furnish the city with a copy of the warranty from the contractor warranting the improvements for one year. After acceptance by the city council, the city shall hand over the mylar and dedication deed with restrictions to the developer for filing. The developer shall provide three recorded copies of the final plat to the city. 
(Code 1962, § 20-9; Ord. No. 1972-14, § 9, 11-7-1972; Ord. No. 1977-8, §§ 5, 6, 3-15-1977; Ord. No. 1999-12, §§ 6-11, 4-1-1999) 
Sec. 102-10. - Submission of as-built plans. 
    The engineer representing the subdivider must present to the city council reproducible mylar complete as-built plans for all paving, drainage structures, water lines and sewer lines within 30 days after completion of each contract. No subdivision will be accepted by the city council until all as-built plans for the subdivision improvements have been filed with the city. 
(Code 1962, § 20-10; Ord. No. 1972-14, § 10, 11-7-1972; Ord. No. 2001-16, § 1, 11-1-2001) 
Sec. 102-11. - Fees. 
(a)  The following schedule of fees and charges shall be paid into the general fund of the city when any subdivision map or plat is tendered to the director of public works, and each of the fees and charges provided in this section shall be paid in advance, and no action of the city council shall be valid until the fee shall have been paid. The director of public works or his deputies or assistants shall calculate the fees and charges in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  Preliminary plats, $100.00 per plat, plus $1.00 per lot. 
(2)  Final plats, $200.00 per plat, plus $2.00 per lot. 
(3)  Areas not designated as lots, $5.00 per acre. 
(b)  The fees set forth in this section shall be charged on all plats, regardless of the action taken by the city council. 
(Code 1962, § 20-11; Ord. No. 1972-14, § 11, 11-7-1972; Ord. No. 1977-8, § 7, 3-15-1977; Ord. No. 1999-12, §§ 12, 13, 4-1-1999) 
Sec. 102-12. - Development of small tracts of land, class A. subdivisions, specifications, requirements. 
(a)  Where city staff recommends and the planning commission concurs that extraordinary hardships or practical difficulties may result from strict compliance with section 102-5 or public interest may be served by an alternative proposal, it may recommend an alternative to these subdivision regulations so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided that such alternatives shall not have the effect of nullifying the general intent and purpose of these regulations; and that pecuniary hardship to the developer, standing alone, shall not be deemed to constitute undue hardship; and further provided that recommendations shall not be made unless they are based upon evidence presented in each specific case that: 
(1)  The granting of the alternative proposal will not be detrimental to the public safety, health or welfare or injurious to other property in the area. 
(2)  The conditions upon which the request for an alternate proposal is based are unique to the property for which the alternative is sought and are not applicable to other property. 
(3)  Because of the particular physical surroundings, shape or topographical conditions of the specific property and/or portions of said property involved, the particular hardship to the owner would result, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience, if the strict terms of these regulations are enforced. 
(4)  The alternative proposal will not in any significant way vary the provisions of the zoning ordinance, zoning map, or comprehensive plan. 
(5)  The granting of the alternative proposal shall not have the effect of preventing the orderly subdivision of other land in the area in accordance with provisions of this section. 
(6)  All improvements shall be constructed in accordance with specifications outlined in the city's subdivision ordinance. 
(7)  Except as provided in the city zoning ordinance, chapter 126, the lot size shall not be less than 5,500 square feet. 
(b)  Conditions can be required that secure standards set by these regulations. 
(c)  The applicant shall submit a petition for any such alternative proposal in writing at the time when the preliminary plat is filed, with review by city staff with recommendations for consideration of the planning commission in accordance with the provisions of this section. The petition shall state fully the grounds for the application; all of the facts and information relied upon for the application. 
(Ord. No. 2005-03, § 1, 1-6-2005; Ord. No. 2007-16, § II, 11-1-2007) 
Chapter 106 - TAXATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- General taxing authority, § 2.01, art. IX, § 13.13. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-8(2); any contract or obligation assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-8(3); any appropriation ordinance or ordinance providing for the levy of taxes or for an annual budget saved from repeal, § 1-8(9); any ordinance relating to local improvements and assessments for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-8(11); administration, ch. 2; businesses, ch. 22. 
State constitution reference- Taxation and revenue, art. VIII. 
State Law reference- Property taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 1.01 et seq.; local occupation taxes, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 101.008; occupation taxes generally, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 191.081 et seq.; local taxation, V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 301 et seq. 

Sec. 106-1. - Exemption from ad valorem tax for aged and totally disabled persons. 
(a)  Sixteen thousand six hundred dollars of the market value of residential homesteads, as defined by law, of persons who have attained the age of 65 years or older for a portion of a tax year for which the exemption is claimed, or of persons who have been determined by the Social Security Administration to be totally disabled, shall be exempt from city ad valorem taxes as provided by the Texas Property Tax Code. 
(b)  In order to secure the benefit of the exemption, the owner shall file an exemption application form with the chief appraiser of the county appraisal district. 
(Code 1962, § 20A-1; Ord. No. 1972-17, § § 1, 2, 12-5-1972; Ord. No. 1976-8, § 1, 6-15-1976; Ord. No. 1980-07, § 1, 7-7-1980; Ord. No. 1999-13, 4-1-1999) 
Sec. 106-2. - Tax on telecommunications services. 
(a)  A tax is hereby authorized on all telecommunications services sold within the city. For purposes of this section, the sale of telecommunications services is consummated at the location of the telephone or other telecommunications device from which the call or other communication originates. If the point of origin cannot be determined, the sale is consummated at the address to which the call or other communication is billed. 
(b)  The application of the exemption provided for in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210(a) is hereby repealed by the city, as authorized by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210(b). 
(c)  The rate of tax imposed by this section shall be the same as the rate imposed by the city for all other local sales and use taxes, as authorized by the legislature of the state. 
(Code 1962, § 20A-2(a)-(c); Ord. No. 1987-07, § 1, 6-18-1987) 
Sec. 106-3. - Occupation tax. 
    There is hereby levied and there shall be collected, from every person pursuing any occupation taxed by the general laws of the state, an annual occupation tax, equal in each instance to one-half of the state occupation tax, which taxes shall be paid annually, in advance, except where otherwise provided by state law, in which event the taxes may be paid as provided by state law. 
(Code 1962, § 20A-3; Ord. No. 1995-11, § 2, 9-7-1995) 
Sec. 106-4. - Sales and use tax. 
    There is hereby levied and there shall be collected a one percent local sales and use tax within the city, as provided by the Municipal Sales and Use Tax Act of the State of Texas, V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 321, and subsequent amendments thereto. 
(Code 1962, § 20A-4; Ord. No. 1995-11, § 2, 9-7-1995) 
Sec. 106-5. - Tax on leased motor vehicles. 
(a)  Pursuant to and in accordance with section 11.252(f) of the Texas Tax Code, the city council of the City of Port Neches hereby declares its intent to assess a tax on leased motor vehicles that are not used for commercial purposes. 
(b)  The tax rate for such leased motor vehicles shall be in an amount set by city council from year to year as part of the budget and taxing process, or as may otherwise be approved from time to time in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 2001-18, § 1, 2, 12-20-2001) 
Sec. 106-6. - Goods-in-transit. 
    The goods-in transit, as defined in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.253(a)(2), as amended by Senate Bill 1, enacted by the 82nd Texas Legislature in special session, shall remain subject to taxation by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-14, 11-15-2007; Ord. No. 2011-21, 11-17-2011) 
Chapter 110 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Regulation of use of streets, § 2.01. 
Cross reference- Any ordinances or resolutions prescribing traffic regulations for specific streets, such as ordinances or resolutions designating one-way streets, no-parking areas, stop intersections where traffic is to be controlled by signals, etc., saved from repeal, § 1-8(14); courts, ch. 34; law enforcement, ch. 62; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 78; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; vehicles for hire, ch. 118; off-street parking spaces, § 126-25. 
State Law reference- Powers of local authorities, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.201 et seq.; placing and maintaining traffic control devices, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 544.002 et seq., 545.101(e), 545.252; stopping, standing and parking, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.301 et seq.; speed restrictions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.351 et seq.; accidents and accident reports, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 550.001 et seq.; pedestrians, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 552.001 et seq.; Texas Traffic Safety Act, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 723.001 et seq.; regulation of parking, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 431.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 110-1. - Traffic division of police department. 
(a)  Established; supervision. There is hereby established in the police department of the city a traffic division, to be under the control of and directly responsible to the chief of police. 
(b)  Duties generally. It shall be the duty of the traffic division to enforce the street traffic regulations of the city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in the city, to make arrests for traffic violations, to investigate accidents and to cooperate with other officers of the city in the administration of the traffic laws, and to carry out those duties specially imposed upon the division by this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city. 
(c)  Studies of traffic accidents. Whenever traffic accidents at any particular location in the city become numerous, the traffic division of the police department shall conduct studies of such accidents and determine remedial measures, if any. 
(d)  Designation of identification for and routes to be used by funeral processions. The traffic division of the police department shall designate a type of pennant or other identifying insignia to be displayed, or other method to be employed, to identify the vehicles in funeral processions and designate routes to be taken within the city by funeral processions. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 2, §§ 1-4; Code 1962, §§ 22-2-22-5; Ord. No. 1998-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-2-1998) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate processions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(3). 
Sec. 110-2. - Duty of police officers to enforce traffic regulations. 
    It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department, or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police, to enforce all street traffic laws of the city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in the city. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 3, § 7; Code 1962, § 22-10) 
Sec. 110-3. - Authority of police officers to direct traffic. 
    Officers of the police department, or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police, are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with this chapter and other traffic laws, provided that, in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter and other traffic laws. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 3, § 8; Code 1962, § 22-11) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate traffic by means of police officers, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(1). 
Sec. 110-4. - Authority of officers of fire department to direct traffic. 
    Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity thereof. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 3, § 7; Code 1962, § 22-12) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50. 
Sec. 110-5. - Obedience to traffic officers. 
    No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer or of a fire department official invested by this chapter or other law with authority to direct, control or regulate traffic. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 3, § 9; Code 1962, § 22-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.501. 
Sec. 110-6. - Riding on portion of vehicle not intended for use of passengers. 
    No person shall ride upon any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designated or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to any employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 15, § 92; Code 1962, § 22-17) 
Sec. 110-7. - Noise from vehicle loads. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle along or upon any public street or alley in the city, which vehicle is loaded with iron or other material likely to produce a great or disturbing sound, without using proper deadening substances to prevent disturbing noises. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 10, § 44; Code 1962, § 22-18) 
Sec. 110-8. - Permit for parades. 
    No procession or parade, other than a funeral procession, containing 50 or more persons or ten or more vehicles, except the forces of the United States army or navy and the military forces of the state, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street except in accordance with a permit issued by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 10, § 40; Code 1962, § 22-19) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate or prohibit processions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(3). 
Sec. 110-9. - Quiet zones. 
    The chief of police, as authorized from time to time by the city council, may designate areas of the streets of the city, to be known as quiet zones, in the vicinity of any hospital, church, school or public institution, and mark such areas with appropriate signs directing the drivers of vehicles not to sound a horn or other warning device while traveling in the areas thus designated, and it shall be unlawful for any person to sound any horn or other warning device in violation of such signs. The fact that such a zone has been designated, as indicated by such signs, shall be prima facie evidence that the designation was authorized by the city council. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 5, § 25a; Code 1962, § 22-25) 
Sec. 110-10. - Obstruction of view of traffic by plants or signs. 
    Trees, shrubs, bushes, plants, grass or weeds growing at or near an intersection in such a manner as to obstruct the view of the approaching traffic from the right or left, or signs or other property located at or near an intersection in such a manner as to obstruct the view of the approaching traffic from the right or left, are hereby declared a nuisance, and the chief of police is hereby authorized to remove such plants or signs. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 15, § 87; Code 1962, § 22-26; Ord. No. 1998-28, § 3, 7-2-1998) 
Charter reference- Abatement of nuisances, § 13.13. 
Sec. 110-11. - Engine braking prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to use or operate or cause to be used or operated within the limits of the city any engine brake or compression brake designed to aid in the braking or deceleration of any vehicle that results in excessive, loud, unusual, explosive or unmuffled noise from such vehicle, except in an emergency situation. 
    This shall also include the production of excessive noise produced by engine retarders due to a truck operating with improperly maintained, defective or modified muffler systems or the use of straight exhaust pipes with no mufflers. 
    Persons who shall violate a provision of this section or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of $500.00. Each day that a violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2010-10, § I, 5-6-2010) 
Secs. 110-12-110-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-31. - One-way streets. 
(a)  Designation and marking. The chief of police is hereby authorized to cause any street or section or portion thereof to be designated and maintained as a one-way street and to designate the direction in which vehicles shall lawfully travel thereon, as may be authorized by the city council from time to time. Whenever any street is so designated, the chief of police shall cause the street to be identified as a one-way street by signs or markings painted on the surface of the street or by clearly visible and uniform signs erected adjacent thereto, or both, which signs or markings shall indicate the designation of such street as a one-way street and the direction on which vehicles shall lawfully travel by arrows pointing in that direction. Such signs or markings shall be erected or painted at each entrance to the one-way street and at each cross intersection and at such other points as may be deemed advisable by the chief of police. The fact that a one-way street has been designated as indicated by appropriate signs and markings painted or erected as provided in this section shall be prima facie evidence that the chief of police was authorized by the city council to designate the street and that it was determined by the city council that the street should be designated according to such markings and signs as they then exist. 
(1)  A one-way street designation, with all traffic traveling north on Heisler Street between Block Street and Wagner Street, during school days held at Woodcrest Elementary School. The one-way traffic shall be on each school day that school is in session for the students between the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. 
(b)  Driving in wrong direction. Whenever any street has been designated as a one-way street as provided in subsection (a) of this section, it shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle to drive the vehicle upon or over such street in a direction other than that determined and indicated by the appropriate signs and markings conforming to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Crossing from one lane to another. On one-way streets which are marked into traffic lanes by solid lines and dash stripes, it shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to pass from one traffic lane into another in any intersection or across any solid line. Crossing from any such lane to another shall only be made at dash stripes and only after a proper hand signal is given. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 8, §§ 33, 34; Code 1962, §§ 22-46-22-48; Ord. No. 2018-04, § I, 7-19-2018 ) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to designate one-way highways and require vehicles thereon to move in one specific direction, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(10); designation of one-way highways not effective until signs are posted, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.203(b). 
Sec. 110-32. - Restrictions on turning. 
(a)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to cause any street intersection to be designated as an intersection at which no U-turn shall be made, or at which no right turn shall be made, or at which no left turn shall be made, and to cause any street intersection to be designated as an intersection at which no turn shall be made, as may be authorized by the city council from time to time. The chief of police is further authorized to cause appropriate signs and markings to be painted on the surface of the street or intersection or clearly visible and uniform signs to be erected at such intersection indicating that it has been designated as an intersection at which no U-turn shall be made, or as an intersection at which no right turn shall be made, or as an intersection at which no left turn shall be made, or as an intersection at which no turn shall be made. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle to make a U-turn with such vehicle being driven or operated by him at any place on a street except at a street intersection which has not been designated as an intersection at which no U-turn or no left turn shall be made, and at which intersection no signs or markings have been painted indicating that it is an intersection designated as an intersection at which no U-turn or no left turn shall be made. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle to make a right turn at any intersection which has been designated as an intersection at which no right turn shall be made, and it shall be unlawful for operator of a vehicle to make a left turn at an intersection that has been designated as an intersection at which no left turn shall be made, and it shall be unlawful for the operator of a motor vehicle to make any turn at an intersection which has been designated as an intersection at which no turn shall be made, and at which intersection signs or markings have been painted or erected indicating that no right turn, no left turn or no turn shall be made, as the case may be. 
(d)  The fact that an intersection has been designated as an intersection at which turning is restricted as provided in this section, as indicated by appropriate signs or markings erected or painted in accord with this section, shall be prima facie evidence that the chief of police was authorized by the city council to make such designation and that it was determined by the council that such intersection should be designated according to such signs or markings as they then exist. 
(Code 1962, § 22-50) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prohibit turning at intersections, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(7). 
Sec. 110-33. - Driving between vehicles of authorized procession. 
    No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles composing a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required by the traffic division in accord with section 110-1(d). 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 10, § 39; Code 1962, § 22-59) 
Sec. 110-34. - Driving in sidewalk area. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 10, § 41; Code 1962, § 22-60) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 
Sec. 110-35. - Driving on fresh pavement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle upon any portion of any street in the city that has been freshly paved, unless all barriers or signal lights have been lawfully removed therefrom, indicating that the street is ready for travel. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 10, § 45; Code 1962, § 22-62) 
Sec. 110-36. - Truck routes. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following words, terms and phrases, whenever and wherever used in this section, shall have the scope and meaning defined and set out in this subsection: 
    Commercial vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled and designated, maintained or used primarily for the transportation of property and has a gross vehicular weight of 7,500 pounds or more, and every trailer with a gross vehicular weight of 7,500 pounds or more. 
    Local commercial vehicle means any commercial vehicle whose origin and/or destination is within or without the city, and any locally operated commercial vehicle. 
    Through commercial vehicle means any commercial vehicle whose origin and destination is other than the city. 
(b)  Permitted routes for through commercial vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a through commercial vehicle upon any street, boulevard, avenue or alley within the limits of the city, except that such commercial vehicle may travel or be operated upon any street, boulevard or avenue designated as a U.S. or a state highway, or as a truck route. 
(c)  Permitted routes for local commercial vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any local commercial vehicle upon any street, boulevard, avenue or alley within the limits of the city, except on a designated U.S. or state highway, or a designated truck route. Subject to the provisions of subsection (e) of this section, a local commercial vehicle may leave any designated U.S. or state highway, or a designated truck route, and travel on any street, boulevard, avenue or alley within the city for the purpose of delivering or picking up goods, wares, materials and/or merchandise, or returning to its established place of business or home. When a local commercial vehicle enters a street, boulevard, avenue or alley as permitted in this subsection, such vehicle shall enter such street, boulevard, avenue or alley at the intersection nearest the point of pickup or delivery or its established place of business or home and return to the truck route by the nearest route. Where more than one pickup or delivery is required, additional pickups or deliveries may be made, and the vehicle shall not be required to return to the truck route after each individual pickup or delivery, but shall return to the truck route upon completion of all pickups or deliveries. 
(d)  Truck routes established. Every U.S. and state highway within the limits of the city is hereby designated as a truck route under the terms of this section, and the following streets, avenues, roads and highways are hereby designated truck routes by name, as follows: 
Grigsby Avenue, from the city limits on the east, west and to its intersection with Merriman Street. 
Magnolia Avenue, also known as Highway No. 366. 
Nall Street, also known as Highway No. 365, from the city limits on the south to its intersection with Magnolia Avenue, or Highway No. 366. 
Nederland Avenue, from its intersection with Magnolia Avenue, or Highway No. 366, north to its intersection with Port Neches Avenue. 
Port Neches Avenue, from its intersection with Nederland Avenue east to the 1900 block thereof. 
(e)  Limited truck routes established. The following streets are hereby designated limited truck routes, i.e., only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on weekdays: 
Lee Street, from its intersection with Merriman Street west through its intersection with Block Street. 
Merriman Street, from its intersection with Grigsby Avenue north to its intersection with Lee Street. 
No commercial vehicle shall drive upon or across a limited truck route at any time other than the hours enumerated in this subsection. 
(f)  Marking of truck routes. The director of public works shall mark the truck routes established in this section by the erection of suitable signs. 
(g)  Penalty. A violation of this section is a class C misdemeanor, and any person who shall violate any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(Code 1962, § 22-64; Ord. No. 1979-12, §§ 1, 2, 5-21-1979; Ord. No. 1998-28, § 9, 7-2-1998) 
Sec. 110-37. - Negligent collision. 
(a)  If any person, while driving or operating or in charge of any vehicle within the city, shall, by negligence, cause or suffer or permit the vehicle to come in collision with any other vehicle, or with any animal, person or property in or on any public street, avenue, roadway, or any public place whatever in the city, such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Proof of no intent to injure shall be no defense to a charge of violating this section. 
(c)  The term "negligence," as used in subsection (a) of this section, is defined to mean the want of such care and caution as a person of ordinary prudence would use under like circumstances. 
(Ord. of 1-3-1949, art. 10, § 46; Code 1962, § 22-65) 
Sec. 110-38. - Improper acceleration. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to start and accelerate a stopped motor vehicle or accelerate a moving vehicle on a public street or any other public property in such a manner to cause the driving wheels to spin and thereby create a loud screeching noise or to accelerate such a motor vehicle in such a manner as to cause the rear portion of the motor vehicle to sway or swing from side to side. 
(b)  Any person who violates any provision of this section or who shall neglect to comply with the terms of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall on conviction thereof be fined in accordance with section 1-7, which carries a maximum fine of $500.00. 
(Code 1962, § 22-66; Ord. No. 1975-14, § 1, 10-21-1975; Ord. No. 1998-28, § 10, 7-2-1998; Ord. No. 2010-21, § I, 9-16-2010) 
Sec. 110-39. - Driving motor vehicle, motorcycle or bicycle on area not designated for traffic. 
(a)  Prohibition. No person shall drive, and it shall be unlawful to operate, a motorcycle, motor vehicle or bicycle upon or over any public or private property within the city except upon public roadways, officially designated motorcycle or bicycle trails, and areas designated for vehicular traffic. 
(b)  Defense. It shall be an affirmative defense in a prosecution under this section that the defendant was operating the motorcycle, motor vehicle or bicycle on private property with the prior written consent of the owner of such property or his agent. 
(c)  Definitions. The words "motorcycle," "motor vehicle" and "bicycle," when used in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in the Texas Transportation Code and its future amendments. 
(d)  Exceptions. The acts proscribed in subsection (a) of this section shall not apply or be applicable to authorized emergency vehicles as defined by the Texas Transportation Code. 
(Code 1962, §§ 22-138-22-141; Ord. No. 1975-1, § 1, 1-21-1975; Ord. No. 1998-28, §§ 15, 16, 7-2-1998) 
Sec. 110-40. - Definitions. 
    City street means a road, street, way, thoroughfare, or bridge over which the city has legislative jurisdiction under its police powers. 
    Daytime means the period beginning one-half hour before sunrise and ending one-half hour after sunset. 
    Golf cart has the meaning assigned by the V.T.C.A. Transportation Code, § 502.001. Further, golf cart means a motor vehicle with not less than three wheels designed by the manufacturer primarily for transporting persons on a golf course without regard to the mode of propulsion or any modifications made to the body, chassis, or any portion of the golf cart by any person. Golf carts specifically exclude go-carts, neighborhood electric vehicles, off-road vehicles, utility vehicles, and all-terrain vehicles, as defined by the Texas Transportation Code. 
    License means a license or permit to operate a motor vehicle issued by a state. 
    Operate has the meaning assigned by V.T.C.A. Transportation Code, § 724.001. 
    Operator means a person who drives or is in control of a golf cart. 
    Owner has the meaning assigned by V.T.C.A. Transportation Code, § 502.001. 
    Public highway has the meaning assigned by V.T.C.A. Transportation Code, § 502.001. 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § I, 6-2-2011) 
Sec. 110-41. - Limited operation. 
    An operator may operate a golf cart in compliance with V.T.C.A. Transportation Code, § 551.403 as amended or superseded, on a public highway within the corporate city limits for which the posted speed limit is not more than 35 miles per hour, if the golf cart is operated: 
• During the daytime; and 
• Not more than two miles from the location where the golf cart is usually parked and for transportation to and from a golf course. 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § I, 6-2-2011) 
Sec. 110-42. - Use within corporate boundaries. 
    Golf carts may be operated within the corporate city limits on all or part of a city street with a posted speed limit of not more than 35 miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § I, 6-2-2011) 
Sec. 110-43. - Crossing certain roadways. 
    A golf cart may cross intersections, including a road or street that has a posted speed limit of more than 35 miles per hour, provided said crossing is at an intersection and is perpendicular to the public highway or city street. 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § I, 6-2-2011) 
Sec. 110-44. - Equipment and other requirements. 
(a)  A golf cart must have the following minimum equipment to operate within the corporate city limits: 
(1)  Head lamps; 
(2)  Tail lamps; 
(3)  Reflectors; 
(4)  Parking brake; 
(5)  Mirrors; 
(6)  Slow-moving vehicle emblem that: 
a.  Has a reflective surface designed to be clearly visible in daylight at a distance of at least 500 feet; 
b.  Is mounted base down on the rear of the golf cart at a height from three to five feet above the road surface; and 
c.  Is maintained in a clean, reflective condition. 
(b)  A person operating a golf cart on a public highway or a city street within the corporate city limits must be in compliance with state law pertaining to financial responsibility and the slow-moving vehicle emblem where said law is applicable to and not excluded from the operation of golf carts. 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § I, 6-2-2011) 
Sec. 110-45. - Unlawful operation and use. 
(a)  It is an offense for any person to operate a golf cart on a public highway or city street within the corporate city limits: 
(1)  Without a valid license; 
(2)  With a posted speed limit of more than 35 miles per hour, except when crossing as permitted by section 110-42; 
(3)  By crossing said public highway or city street, except as permitted by section 110-43; 
(4)  By failing to comply with the equipment and other requirements set forth in section 110-44; and 
(5)  By failing to move to the right and yield the right-of-way to motor vehicles. 
(b)  It is an offense for any person, while operating a golf cart and; 
(1)  While the golf cart is in motion, to fail to remain seated or to fail to require every occupant of the golf cart to remain seated in a seat designed to hold passengers; or 
(2)  To allow any occupant of the golf cart to ride in the lap of the operator or any other occupant. 
(c)  It is an offense for the owner of a golf cart to allow any person to operate said golf cart in a manner that violates sections 110-41 through 110-45. 
(d)  It is an offense for any person to operate a golf cart on a public highway within the corporate city limits, except as allowed by section 110-41. 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § I, 6-2-2011) 
Sec. 110-46. - Penalties. 
    Persons who shall violate a provision of this subsection or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. Each violation is a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § I, 6-2-2011) 
Secs. 110-47-110-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate traffic by means of traffic control devices and signals, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(1). 

Sec. 110-61. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00 and not more than $500.00. 
(Code 1962, § 22-80; Ord. No. 1981-11, § 1, 3-20-1981) 
Sec. 110-62. - General standards; conformity with state manual. 
    All traffic control devices, including signs, signals and markings (pavement and/or curb), installed or used for the purpose of directing and controlling traffic within the city shall conform with the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways, Volumes I and II (referred to in this article as the "manual"). The Texas Transportation Code states that all signs, signals, and markings erected or used by the city shall be uniform and shall be located, so far as practicable, according to the directions shown in the manual throughout the city. All existing traffic control devices and those erected in the future by the city being consistent with the manual, state law and this article shall be official traffic control devices. 
(Code 1962, § 22-72; Ord. No. 1981-11, § 1, 3-20-1981; Ord. No. 1998-28, § 11, 7-2-1998) 
Sec. 110-63. - Obedience. 
    The driver of any vehicle, motor vehicle or animal shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device, sign, signal, or marking applicable thereto placed in accordance with this article, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted drivers of authorized emergency vehicles and to the Texas Transportation Code. 
(Code 1962, § 22-73; Ord. No. 1981-11, § 1, 3-20-1981; Ord. No. 1998-28, § 12, 7-2-1998) 
Sec. 110-64. - Installation. 
(a)  The city council shall, by ordinance, direct that the chief of police shall have the duty of erecting or installing, upon, over, along, or beside any highway, street or alley, signs, signals and markings, or causing such signs, signals and markings to be erected, installed, or placed, in accordance with this article and consistent with the manual. The traffic control devices shall be installed immediately, or as soon as such specific device, sign, or signal can be procured. 
(b)  Whenever the chief of police has erected and installed any official traffic control device, signal, or sign at any location in the city, or has caused such work to be done under his direction, in obedience to this article and the manual, he shall thereafter file a report with the city secretary, in writing, and signed officially by the chief of police, stating the type of traffic control device, sign, or signal, and when and where the device, sign or signal was erected and/or installed. The city secretary shall file and maintain such report of the chief of police among the official papers of the office of the city secretary. 
(Code 1962, § 22-75; Ord. No. 1981-11, § 1, 3-20-1981) 
Sec. 110-65. - Permit to erect detour signs. 
    Contractors or other persons desiring to erect detour signs on streets before, during or after construction work shall, before erecting such detour or barricade signs, obtain the written permission of the chief of police to do so, who shall notify the fire department, the police department and the director of public works immediately upon granting such permission. 
(Code 1962, § 22-76; Ord. No. 1981-11, § 1, 3-20-1981) 
Sec. 110-66. - Display of unauthorized signs, signals or markings. 
(a)  A person may not place, maintain, or display on or in view of a highway an unauthorized sign, signal, marking, or device that: 
(1)  Imitates or resembles an official traffic control device or railroad sign or signal; 
(2)  Attempts to direct the movement of traffic; or 
(3)  Hides from view or hinders the effectiveness of an official traffic control device or railroad sign or signal. 
(b)  A person may not place or maintain on a highway, and a public authority may not permit on a highway, a traffic sign or signal bearing commercial advertising. 
(c)  A person may not place or maintain a flashing light or flashing electric sign within 1,000 feet of an intersection except under a permit issued by the state transportation commission. 
(d)  This section does not prohibit a person from placing on private property adjacent to a highway a sign that gives useful directional information and that cannot be mistaken for an official sign. 
(e)  A sign, signal, light, or marking prohibited under this section is a public nuisance. The chief of police may remove that sign, signal, light, or marking without notice. 
(Code 1962, § 22-77; Ord. No. 1981-11, § 1, 3-20-1981) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 544.006. 
Sec. 110-67. - Presumption regarding validity of traffic control devices. 
    It being unlawful for any person other than the chief of police, acting pursuant to an ordinance of the city, to install or cause to be installed any signal, sign, or device purporting to direct the use of the streets, or the activities on those streets of pedestrians, vehicles, motor vehicles, or animals, proof, in any prosecution for a violation of this article, or any traffic ordinance of the city, that any traffic control device, sign, signal, or marking was actually in place on any street shall constitute prima facie evidence that the device, sign, signal or marking was installed by the chief of police, pursuant to the authority of this article, and of the ordinance directing the installation of such device, signal, or marking. 
(Code 1962, § 22-78; Ord. No. 1981-11, § 1, 3-20-1981) 
Secs. 110-68-110-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SPEED 

Sec. 110-91. - Generally. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate a motor vehicle within the city at a rate of speed greater than 30 miles per hour. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no person shall drive a motor vehicle on any street or highway in the city at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing, having regard to the actual and potential hazards when approaching or crossing an intersection or a railway grade crossing, when approaching or going around a curve, when approaching a hill crest, when traveling upon a narrow or winding street or highway, or when a special hazard exists with respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of weather or street conditions. In every event, speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering the street or highway in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(Code 1962, § 22-41) 
State Law reference- Speed restrictions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.351 et seq.; authority of municipality to alter speed limits, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.356. 
Sec. 110-92. - Twelve miles per hour zones. 
    In the following areas and on the designated portions of the following streets, the speed limit shall be 12 miles per hour, which limit shall be designated by proper signs, and it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle in excess of such limit: 
In that area being used as a public park and for other recreational facilities, being bound on the north by the Neches River, on the east by Park Street extended, on the south by Grigsby Drive, and on the west by Merriman Street. This description has no intent of including Grigsby Street or Merriman Street. 
(Res. of 8-16-1954; Res. of 9-12-1955; Res. of 2-4-1957; Code 1962, § 22-42; Ord. No. 1998-27, § 1, 7-2-1998; Ord. No. 1998-28, § 4, 7-2-1998) 
Sec. 110-93. - Fifteen miles per hour zones. 
(a)  In the following areas and on the designated portions of the following streets, during the hours of 7:30 a.m. until 8:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. until 3:30 p.m., or as otherwise posted upon appropriate school zone signs, or during periods when lights are flashing on school zone signs, the speed limit shall be 15 miles per hour, which limit shall be designated by proper signs, and it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle in excess of such limit in any of the following school areas: 
(1)  Ridgewood Elementary: 
From South Avenue along Merriman Street in a southerly direction to a point 100 feet beyond the southeast corner of the Ridgewood Elementary School property line. 
(2)  Woodcrest Elementary: 
Heisler Street from Block Street to Wagner Street. 
(3)  Port Neches Elementary School and Port Neches Middle School: 
Central from Llano to Merriman Street. 
Llano from Highway 366 north to Gulf Avenue. 
A portion of the 2000 and 2100 blocks of Merriman, 150 feet south of the Port Neches Middle School property line, extending 150 feet north of Central Avenue. 
(4)  Port Neches Groves High School: 
Avenue D between Park Street and Merriman. 
Merriman Street from the intersection of Hebert Woods Drive with Merriman Street north on Merriman Street to its intersection with Avenue C. 
Park Street from Avenue D south to Avenue L. 
(b)  In the following areas and on the designated portions of the following streets, during the hours of 7:30 a.m. until 8:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. until 3:30 p.m., or as otherwise posted upon appropriate school zone signs, or during periods when lights are flashing on school zone signs, the speed limit shall be 20 miles per hour, which limit shall be designated by proper signs, and it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle in excess of such limit in any of the following school areas: 
[(1)]  Alternative Campus: 
a.  A portion of the 1700 block of Port Neches Avenue, from Montrose east a distance of 125 feet. 
b.  A portion of the 1200 block of Montrose, from Port Neches Avenue north a distance of 235 feet. 
(Res. of 1-23-1961; Code 1962, § 22-43; Ord. No. 1998-28, § 5, 7-2-1998; Ord. No. 2010-20, § I, 9-16-2010; Ord. No. 2015-02, § I, 2-19-2015 ) 
Sec. 110-94. - Twenty miles per hour zones. 
    The speed limit on the designated portions of the following streets shall be 20 miles per hour, which limit shall be designated by proper signs, and it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle at a speed in excess of such limit: 
(1)  Merriman Street from Grigsby Drive to Lee Street, all of West Drive, all of Montrose and all of MacArthur. 
(2)  Lee Street from Merriman Street to Montgomery Street. 
(3)  Herring Drive. 
(4)  The 1200 and 1300 blocks of Pine Lane. 
(Res. of 6-20-1961; Code 1962, § 22-44; Ord. No. 1996-11, § 1, 7-18-1996; Ord. No. 1996-15, § 1, 7-18-1996; Ord. No. 1997-07, § 1, 6-19-1997; Ord. No. 1998-27, § 1, 7-2-1998; Ord. No. 1998-28, § 6, 7-2-1998; Ord. No. 2015-02, § II, 2-19-2015 ) 
Sec. 110-95. - Twenty-five miles per hour zones. 
    The speed limit on the following designated streets shall be 25 miles per hour, which limit shall be designated by proper signs, and it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle at a speed in excess of such limit: 
Caroline Street. 
Combs Drive. 
Diana Street. 
Earle Street. 
Gist Drive. 
Hampton Lane. 
Kirkwood Drive. 
Landry Drive. 
Lofton Drive. 
Mazur Drive. 
Saba Lane beginning at the 2600 block north through Keith Estates. 
Saba Lane from Gist Drive to the 2700 block of Saba Lane. 
Sasser Lane. 
Sierra Drive. 
Staton Lane. 
Victor Drive. 
(Code 1962, § 22-44.1; Ord, No. 1976-7, § 1, 6-15-1976; Ord. No. 1978-09, § 1, 6-19-1978; Ord. No. 1995-01, § 1, 1-5-1995) 
Sec. 110-96. - Forty miles per hour zones. 
    On the designated portions of the following streets, the speed limit shall be 40 miles per hour, which limit shall be designated by proper signs, and it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle at a speed in excess of such limit: 
Port Neches Avenue from Highway No. 366 to a point 250 feet north of the intersection of Port Neches Avenue and Fifth Street. 
(Res. of 5-6-1957; Code 1962, § 22-45; Ord. No. 1998-29, § 1, 7-2-1998; Ord. No. 2000-12, § 1, 4-6-2000) 
Sec. 110-97. - Forty-five miles per hour zones. 
    On the designated portions of the following streets, the speed limit shall be 45 miles per hour, which limit shall be designated by proper signs, and it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle at a speed in excess of such limit: 
Old Atlantic Highway from Orchard Avenue to the east city limit line. 
(Code 1962, § 22-45.2; Ord. No. 1975-6, § 1, 6-3-1975; Ord. No. 1998-28, § 8, 7-2-1998) 
Sec. 110-98. - Speed zone strip map for F.M. 365. 
(a)  The maximum legal speed limits of all vehicles in the city limits on the following highways shall be set forth in each zone as shown on the speed zone strip map attached to Ordinance No. 1964-7, based on 85 percentile speed, and traffic and engineering investigations made by the state department of transportation. The speed zone strip map is hereby made a part of this section and is as follows:

(b)  Any person who violates any provision of this section or who shall neglect to comply with the terms of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall on conviction thereof be fined in any sum not less than $1.00 and not more than $500.00, and the violation of the posted maximum speed in each zone of the speed zone strip map and each day each maximum speed in each zone is violated constitutes a separate offense. 
(Code 1962, § 22-45.1; Ord. No. 1964-7, §§ 1, 2, 5-19-1964) 
Editor's note- The speed zone strip map referred to in the above section is not included herein, but may be found on file in the office of the city secretary. 
Sec. 110-99. - Speed zone strip map for state-maintained highways. 
(a)  The maximum legal speed limits of all vehicles in the city limits on the following highways shall be as set forth in each zone as shown on the speed zone strip map attached to Ordinance No. 1998-32, based on 85 percentile speed, and traffic and engineering investigations made by the state department of highways and public transportation. The speed zone strip map is hereby made a part of this section and is as follows:

(Code 1962, § 22-45.3(a), (b); Ord. No. 1975-10, § 1, 8-19-1975; Ord. No. 1998-32, § 1(a), (b), 7-16-1998; Ord. No. 2013-07, § 2, 6-20-2013) 
Editor's note- The speed zone strip map referred to in the above section is not included herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city secretary.
